number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Visually fascinating, with some brilliant sound design, this is an immersive lush world to get lost into for an hour or two, surreal and unsettling yet soothing at the same time. It's a game allright, but it's really not about the gameplay, that's just a superficial excuse to spend some time in this eery atmosphere.Stripped of its artstyle this would be a mediocre HOG, with some of the most unimaginative puzzles ever. Worse even, the controls are really bad - though it gets less noticeable after the first level (stick it out). Basically, translating the (clearly originally for touchscreens) tap / drag into click / click&drag means the game can't really tell what your input is half the time, which will be quite frustrating for some people.Personally, I wanted to be annoyed by another half baked mobile port and couldn't, and I don't even like insects and flowers that much. It looks stunning on a big screen, the images here hardly do it justice. The music and sound design have the same eerie, mildly unsettling quality as the visuals. The loving attention to detail in both the art and the sound design is really impressive, as is the way they blend and flow together, completely overshadowing everything the gameplay is lacking. I also found the slow pace and even the length (it's short) fitting and appropriate. I enjoyed my time with it, and for anyone after the experience rather than the game, it's definitely worth checking out.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Morphopolis is a point-and-click adventure game that is both beautiful and unique; However its gameplay is slow,boring, and repetative while being relaxing at the same time. After thirty minutes of gameplay I wanted to stop, I was constantly wondering around playing I-Spy with the game. I would say that around 80% of this game is I-Spy with insanely slow movement. The other 20% is spent doing puzzles which were mostly unique and condusing. Overall I would say to only get this game while it's on sale just to see wheter you like it or not. If at full-price, then there is definitely something better to spend your money on.~Pros~+Beautiful Artwork+Unique Artwork+Unique Game Concept+Unique Puzzles+Casual Players Welcome+All Achievements Unlocked in only one Playthrough~Cons~-No Options  -No Controls  -No Audio  -No Video Options-Repetative Gameplay-Repetative Soundtrack-Two Hours of Gameplay -Extremely Slow Gameplay-Buggy Movement-Zero Turtorial or Instruction  -Confusing Gameplay-Only Auto-Saves after each chapter  -If you leave during a 45 minute chapter, you must restart-Can not quit during puzzles  -During puzzles you must manually make the game crash if you want to leave the game; However doing this will make you have to restart the entire chapter, including the puzzle~Verdict~  ~Only buy it if on sale for under a US Dollar  ~I would not recommend buying Morphopolis at the full price of Five US Dollars~That is all~  ~Indie Reviewer Soggy Banana~

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												This game is beautiful. The art is beautiful, the sound is beautiful. It's a beautiful game. It was clearly made by artists, and talented ones at that.Sadly, aritsts do not always make the best game designers. The controls are awkward and confusing, movement is painfully slow and difficult to control, and there are times when a little guidance would be helpful - but none is offered. I'm thinking in particular of one puzzle where the pieces can only be moved as they are in those peg solitaire games - but there is absolutely no indication given of this. There's a whole forum thread full of people wondering why they can't do anything in this puzzle, assuming it's a bug. Difficulty is good, but obtuseness is... less good. Given how many "alpha testers" they list on their credits, I'd have expected them to realize and repair some of these large flawsStill, it's quite short, and as I said, it's very beautiful. At the extremely steep discount it regularly goes for on Steam, I'd say it's worth one play through. If nothing else, it's got trading cards. So I'm recommending it - at a discounted price. I'd like to see more from this developer, but I'd like to see these brilliant artists team up with someone who knows how to design a game.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Interesting concept of the game. Hidden object is the most accurate description, but it certainly isn't a standard game from that genre. There is no story and still you can follow the 'plot' pretty easily.The presentation is unique and the music fits the atmosphere nicely. The animations aren't perfect, but again fit the style of the game very well. The controls aren't that great and guessing where to go and/or how to get there can be a bit frustrating. The controls just work well enough to finish the game, but you will run into some problems with them.Another small issue is that you have to move between screens and it is awfully slow. It's a design decision to include this 'mechanic' into the game, but I don't think that it works particularly well. Still it only slows the rather short game down, so it's really not much of an issue.Is the game worth to play? Yes. Is it worth 5$? Well, no. It is quite short and offers no replay value, so get it in a sale or from a bundle. That being said try to get in the next proper sale, as it is a worthwhile experience :)

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												I received this game as a gift from a good friend.At its heart, Morphopolis plays like a hidden object game with several simple, yet fun puzzles thrown in.The artwork is quite charming, bright and colorful. It would be at home in classic illustrated children's book.If I had one gripe about gameplay is that there is a point and click element to the movement (or more correctly, hold a direction and click) which is quite slow and sometimes it's not obvious what areas of the screen transition to a new area. That said you can at least click on your little bug several times to send out little 'feeler' particles that branch off in the different directions you can move to, although you may have to be much closer than you'd think for this to show you a path you've been missing.It has a simple hint system, clicking the ? in the upper right hand corner will have the game point out an object you can interact with at the time. It has a cool down timer after use, so it's not really abusable. If you've found all there is to do in an area it will simply beep instead of pointing out something, however it still wont tell you where you should go, which again can be a little annoying if you've missed an area transition.The game is short and can be beaten in under two hours, I played it in several short bursts over a couple of days. It may take you longer if you're farming trading cards.Over all, Morphopolis feels like it was aimed at a younger audience. I'd highly recommend it to anyone with child or young adult interested in entomology (the study of insects.) Those who have a marked phobia of insects however, might find the game a little creepy (and crawly).

content:
Posted: February 27
												Morphopolis is an incredibly indulgent and simple game. It is plagued with downright unpleasant controls and confusing mechanics. The first level is the most enjoyable - mostly because it makes sense. You start out as a caterpillar that needs to collect some food, and make another bug move out of your way, so that the caterpillar can get into the right spot, and go into the chrysalis stage. This is not explained in any real fashion - you have to figure the objective out for yourself. I'm okay with not spoonfeeding a player with information, especially in a puzzle game, but Morphopolis does not even explain the controls well enough for you to grasp what you are doing, or are supposed to be doing. It exacerbates this issue by only using one button (the left mouse button) to do every single thing in the game.The second level (through the fourth level) does not have you going through a real stage of metamorphosis, but instead crawling into the head of a larger (dead) insect. Now, I know that there are a couple species of parasites that do this, but not just any cricket or bee can walk into the corpse of another insect like it was the sliding door of a Walgreen's and pilot said insect like that alien from the Men In Black movie - so this idea very much catches you off guard. In practical terms it means you really are just wandering around, completing minor tasks, unsure of where all of your actions are leading until you get there. To make matters worse, the actual mechanics of getting to your new, squishy corpus are painfully slow. For some unknown reason, no matter what form you take, you are the slowest insect to have ever lived. Perhaps it is because your former self is using some kind of Rube Goldberg lever and pulley system to move the new shell? Maybe it is because the insect from the first level is having to manually move each successive leg inside of each body like Ace Ventura inside of a matryoshka doll of rhinos? I digress - the in-game reason matters not, it is the end user experience, that matters. The game forces you to hold the left click button down for the duration of movement until you reach your destination. This mechanic is made all the more painful because, aside from the time spent actually moving, you really only need to spend about 15-20 seconds on each map before needing to switch to another one.The reason for the minimal amount of time needed on each map is is that the bulk of what you do involves collecting objects to appease the other insects on the level so they will let you pass. They demand this of you even though completing the task seems to not actually benefit them in any way. These tasks are mostly fetchquests where the Ace Ventura player-insect shows up on the map and then stands there without interacting with the environment in any way as the player (left) clicks on each bauble. The other tasks involve bringing the baubles to some point on the map and then rearranging them until you solve the "puzzle" they constitute. Sadly, you cannot actually collect these objects as you see them. Instead must wait until you have collected all of the objects for the previous task, return to the insect that gave you the task, and then go find the next insect with the next, inconsequential taskI could honestly go on about the failings of this game - but it really boils down to this: it took me two hours to complete an entire game that easily contained less than half an hour of content. It's too slow, too inexplicable, and too unrewarding to make me feel good about the $.19 I spent on it.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												This is a uniquely beautiful, wordless, hidden object game that focuses on insects.  You guide a variety of insects through five scenarios, collecting body parts and seeds and interacting with other bugs and plants. The movement speed is really slow, but that's the only knock I have. The puzzles are creative and challenging without being overly difficult, and the music, although limited, is very enjoyable.  But the big thing is the graphics - they are very unique in their coloration and style and that makes all the impact.  The game takes a little over an hour for the five scenarios, so it's short but sweet.  Definitely in the category of games as art, with interaction taking a back seat to aesthetics, but still worth the experience.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Morphopolis is a really pretty game, but unfortunately it is barely playable.For a click-and-find type of adventure -- pretty mindless, for the most part -- it is pretty interesting. I bought it (on sale) due to my interest in the graphics, and I wasn't disappointed by them. However, I was disappointed by the gameplay itself. The click-and-drag meant I was constantly putting pressure on my mouse and it got uncomfortable -- it could be made better by utilizing a "tap-to-move" function. Further, it was very slow-moving and the insect seemed to get "confused", direction-wise, making it even more of a hassle to move around. The only part of this game that I did really enjoy was the puzzle parts. They were clever, it was fun having no instructions so you just kind of had to figure them out, and they were a welcome break from the otherwise monotonous game.Unfortunately, the puzzles themselves are not enough for me to recommend this game. If you're looking to buy a pretty game that's also pretty dysfunctional, then look no further; however, if you want a game that you can actually play for fun more than once, I'd definitely look elsewhere.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I was originally drawn in by Morphopolis's vibrant, hand-drawn art. It's color palettes are rich, the environments are complex, and its cast of flora is so lush it almost borders on surreal. It is, without a doubt, one of the most visually stunning hidden object games that I've played  to date.Unfortunately, those stunning visuals make for unclear level layouts and hidden objects that are almost indecipherable from the scenery. The game's graphic elements encourage rampant clicking and inspire frustration in the player when they suddenly discover there's a whole new area they would have known they could explore if they had just climbed up one particular branch (that is, of course, identical to all the other branches that you can't climb). Many of the levels were aesthetically pleasing, but irritatingly busy.The biggest flaw in Morphopolis, however, is the movement speed of your character. Your bug crawls at an agonizingly slow pace and is often confused by the clicks of your mouse, causing them to "dance" back and forth wildly. On top of that, despite being able to spot many hidden objects as you advance through the screens of the level, you can't collect them until you've received a task from another bug. The game forces you to walk back and forth several more times than necessary to collect items you already knew were there.If you can get it for cheap and are a fan of hidden object games I would pick it up just for the art, but otherwise there are more polished hidden object games to spend your time and money on in the Steam store that are guaranteed to give you more fun than the slow, trudging pace of Morphopolis.

												There is one very frustrating thing about this game: each level consists of multiple screens, and to move to another screen you have to tell an insect to walk there. The last puzzle was relatively hard.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												A simple point and click adventure where your goal is to infest a deceased organism larger than yourself. Once you infest the creature you're able to control it and the cycle begins again... as the cycles continue you become the russian nesting doll of parasites... continually collecting resources and infesting more powerful creatures. For what purpose, we may never know, for we are only given a small glimpse into this creature's existence.I give it two thumbs up with high praise of this game's warning to humanity of the evil to come.It's adaptable. It can solve complex puzzles. It bends other creatures to it's will. We're the only ones that know it's coming. We must stop it.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												I wish there was a meh button. Although this game is short its normal price is 1.99, I bought it during a steam sale at a much reduced price, and since I paid less than a quarter I think it lived up to how much I paid. This games doesn't do much hand holding, and its a sort of point and click (more like slide and fumble). Simple story with pretty decent music (which does get to be repetitive after a while) and coloring book style . I would almost recommend it for kids except controling the insect can be frustrating when you can't see the paths availble holding down the mouse right button will show you possible paths and the right button uses your ability. After you know where the things you need and how to solve the puzzels there is little reason to replay this game. Becuase of its price I would recommend this game for people who like simple stories and point and clicks (together)

												This game is beautiful!  The artwork is amazing and vibrant!  The insect movement is smooth and the music is really soothing.  The puzzles are pretty easy up until the very last one.  It took me about 30 minutes to finish... I knew what needed to be done, but I couldnt make my brain see it.  In the end it was a matter of luck.  I dont count that against the game at all... it really made me feel like I had accomplished something.  I recommend this game if you like soothing hidden object games with a bit of puzzle element thrown in.

Posted: March 19, 2016
												Beautiful and charming small puzzle game. I've really enjoyed the calming trip through five maps, full of very detailed, wonderful handdrawn art and hypnotic music, In terms of gameplay this is mostly a hidden object game, with some classic sliding puzzles here and there, varying from easy to tricky. The sometimes troublesome controls, double walking pathes and the lack of real originality in puzzles could weaken my overall very positive impression, but somehow they don't do and I'm sure I will replay this at some point!7/10

Posted: August 16, 2016
												Morphopolis is a stunningly beautiful point and click/hidden object game. Now I usually have some dislike towards hidden object games, but the style presented within Morphopolis makes up for that.There really is no story in Morphopolis. You are an insect who goes through several metamorphic changes. However Morphopolis should not be played for the story. It should be played for the atmosphere. Adding to the very colourful and fantastical world is the soundtrack. Now even though the soundtrack is not quite remarkable or rememberable, it does add to the atmosphere.As with many puzzle games, the learning curve is important. The puzzles within Morphopolis are common throughout the genre. Thus, being common, they are fairly easy, with the last one being the most difficult. That is great for the learning curve, however Morphopolis does not have any creative or new puzzles, which are always welcome in a point and click game. Another flaw is that you move incredibly slowly throughout the level, and if you miss something and have to back track it becomes tedious.With all that being said, Morphopolis is a colourful world on a bare bones hidden object/point and click game. If you want a casual and bright experience, I would pick up Morphopolis on sale as part of the Art Appreciation Pack.

Posted: April 27, 2015
												Morphopolis is a sadistic puzzle game, in which you control the movements of a specimen from the next level of insect evolution. This insect tracks down notably larger dying insects, then patches them up and feeds them, pretends to be their friend. But as soon as the larger insect is healed and ready to move again, the one you control penetrates it's head, burrows it's way inside the poor insects' brain cavity and takes control over their body. Afterwards, you begin to track down the next pray whom to repeat the process on.The game ends in you going inside a tunnel. It is understandable that the developers cut out the following part in which you take over a human, go lay your eggs in the newborn wing of a hospital and watch your children taking control of the newborn humans, and eventually, your race turning every other specie on the planet to mindless controllable puppets.Not recommended for underage audiences.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												Stunning Graphic/Artworks , and the BGM is marvellous .Definitely worth every penny , plus I bought it on Summer Sale (96% yo) ...definetely makes my day :DMorphopolis is a game about bugs, some of the smallest creatures in the world and they are rather fascinating and very important to our environment aswell. This game is a point and click game with puzzles to solve and hidden objects to discover and find, this will help the small bug on its journey of life. This is a very pretty and colourful game, and not very difficult to play.Also you must complete each chapter, if you decide to stop halfway through you will have to start from the beginning of that chapter, as there is no exit feature while in a level so I just completed them and exited the game afterwards.Morphopolis is a very short game and the achievements are easy to earn. I found the last puzzle rather challenging, but I won't doubt that anyone can't managed to solve it and get 100% of theachievements :)

Posted: November 6, 2015
												Morphopolis is a beautiful slow paced hidden object puzzle game. The artwork is mesmerising, the music is calming, and although the controls can be a little awkward at times, I love how smooth the transition between panels is- including the ability to grab last second object as you're already moving offscreen.With regards to the puzzles- the tangled string and beetle swap ones being the best in my opinion, were well thought out and had a challenging yet fun level of difficulty. In retrospect one thing I loved (Though hated at the time) was the complete lack of instruction within the puzzles. On more than one or two I would be sat there wondering what the heck I was even supposed to do (Flower placement puzzle), but it's a great way to get you thinking and working hard for your achievements. All in all, I got this game for about 15p in the Halloween sale, and I really wish I'd paid more for it. £4 would have been a stretch, but I'd say this one is definitely worth £3. At almost 2 hours long, it's a perfect game for a nice chill evening :)

Posted: August 20, 2015
												Very colorful, very detailed, relatively easy, short, relaxing and slightly humorous.€5 Is about the limit this is worth. And that's if you really apreaciate the art. Which I did... but I paid  €0.19. It comes with hints if you're stuck, but you'll likely never will be. It's a lot of collecting of various items and every once in a while you'll go to a puzzle screen. Some items are very well hidden and I do think I got a few lucky clicks in.The puzzles are very easy and I only got stuck once, because I didn't know about a mechanic. Very nice game for a relaxing evening with a glass of wine. Get it on sale, though. Thumbs up from me.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												I really wanted to enjoy this short little game (I'm a fan of Tiny Bang Story) but the lack of even basic control instructions makes the experience far more frustrating than fun. Each level has one mini-game that you must complete to continue. However, there are no indications of any kind to tell you what you are supposed to do in the mini-game, and much worse, there is no exit button from the level! You must tab out to the desktop then use Task Manager to close the game. That is horrible game design! At least Morphopolis is very cheap so you won't feel like a fool for spending too much money if you become frustrated to the point of quitting before finishing.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												(7.5/10)Cute little 'adventure' type game, with a very distinctive art style.  Probably most targeted for those with kids as the cute colors and all the various bugs will definitely be something compatible with kids (though you might want to hang around to help them with the puzzles).The difficulty of the non puzzle bits is a bit easier, making for a relatively relaxed play through.  The only possible frustration is how slow some of your bugs will move, it can drag some levels on when you know you have to collect a certain number of things and you know where they are, but it takes ages for yer bug to crawl from screen to screen.Overall though I did have fun and would come back for more of the art and chill music.

Posted: June 17, 2015
												Great little puzzler. Amazing price.What an enjoyable game this is! There are 5 very colourful levels, with the aim being to 'evolve' It's a hidden object game with a lot of charm.The music is one of the best features. It's a kind of New Age musical rhythm and very apt for the task.Most of the puzzles are very simple, though the last one, in level 5,  was quite tricky and took me the longest. The puzzle in level 4 was easy once I had worked out what I was supposed to be doing.I bought the game for the incredibly low price of  $0.19  and it came with Steam cards. For those that like Steam achievements, the achievemnts in Morphopolis are very starightforward, with all being unlocked as you progress.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												It's a hidden object game that's very different from most games in this genre.Gameplay-wise this is very similar to Tiny Bang Story but it's much better - the objects are not so difficult to find and hints recharge automatically. Part of the game is also figuring out what to do, there are no tasks or instructions, not even for puzzle mini-games. I usually don't like this but here it's ok.And the game has fantastic music and almost mystical atmosphere. Graphics are ok, animations could have been better.Note: 5€ price tag is a bit high for such a short and simple game. I recommend waiting for a sale.

Posted: August 11, 2015
 PROS + Artwork+ Music+ Basically Free if you buy it as part of the currently offered Art Appreciation Pack Bundle and sell the dropped cards.+1 Perfect game in about 1.5 hours (The rest of my playtime consists of the game idling in the background, waiting for the card drops.)+ Relaxing if you manage to not let the terrible controls annoy you. CONS - Terrible Controls: Can you call it "controls" if it's just one button? LMB is used to both direct your bug (hold) and activate stuff (click). Well, your bug constantly gets stuck somewhere, spinning around until you find the perfect angle to unstick him. Also, it sometimes just turns around and walks out of the zone you're in when you click on something. If it weren't for these issues and the incredibly slow walking speed of the bugs, the game could probably be completed in half an hour.- The Puzzle Difficulty seems to be aimed at children, while the complete lack of direction or explanations certainly is not. There's also bugs crawling inside the husks of dead, bigger bugs to somehow take control of their body. So I have no idea what to think. CONCLUSION If there were a "meh" option, this would be the game to use it for. If you're really into it after looking at the gameplay trailer, get it (on sale, if possible). What you see is what you get, i.e. slowly crawling through slightly animated drawings and solving undemanding puzzles in between. It definitely has its uses for playing the Steam Meta Game, so I'm recommending it for that reason alone.

												Love this game! And it is great fun to play with the grandchildren. They all stand around and point to the hidden objects they've found. Yes, your creature is slow and the controls are a bit wonky, but personally I feel it adds to the feel of the game.  Insects are known to be "not smart".  And then a bunch of little voices are all yelling "NO!!! UP, up, up! Not down! The only really difficult puzzel is one on level 4, the rest are pretty easy. There is no save on each level, which is pretty common. Once you have finished a level you can go back any time an redo it. Music is nice and graphics are lovely - and NO violence OR unnecessarily buxom girls at all! Lovely family game. 10/10

This is a very pretty and colourful game, and not very difficult to play.Also you must complete each chapter, if you decide to stop halfway through you will have to start from the beginning of that chapter, as there is no exit feature while in a level so I just completed them and exited the game afterwards.Morphopolis is a very short game and the achievements are easy to earn. I found the last puzzle rather challenging, but I won't doubt that anyone can't managed to solve it and get 100% of theachievements :)

Posted: September 5, 2015
												If you like your hidden object games with obtuse puzzles, obscure objectives, painfully inept controls, contrived parameters for progression, incessant backtracking between screens along with movement so painfully slow it will take literally 20 seconds to move between said screens then this game is for you.Personally I don't enjoy that kind of thing, in fact I found this game such torture I'd recommend its use on prisoners in Guantanamo Bay; I think it would be far more effective than waterboarding.

Posted: March 19, 2016
												Beautiful and charming small puzzle game. I've really enjoyed the calming trip through five maps, full of very detailed, wonderful handdrawn art and hypnotic music, In terms of gameplay this is mostly a hidden object game, with some classic sliding puzzles here and there, varying from easy to tricky. The sometimes troublesome controls, double walking pathes and the lack of real originality in puzzles could weaken my overall very positive impression, but somehow they don't do and I'm sure I will replay this at some point!7/10

Posted: November 21, 2015
												Goodness, what can be said about this game? It's fairly short (finished it in about two hours myself), depending on how quickly you figure out said game's mechanics, and it came go quickly. It's odd watching your character, if you can even call it that since it's a small bug you control, change and 'metamorphosis' into another bug and onward. Clicking and very heavily needed on back and forth searching for the hidden objects around the level, some things are hidden in one area are needed for something that is in an area back in the beginning of the level while others are needed for later on in said level or higher up towards something at the top of the screen, items are needed to persuade certain other bugs to let you pass and it can get frustrating, but it's a calming game once you get around to figuring out how to do so.It's a mixed sort of game, if you are into puzzle solving and hidden games, you might like this small short game, if not then stay away since you could get confused and show great regret in buying in, all in all it is just up to the person who wants to buy it, I recomend it to those puzzle lovers and those who like hidden objects.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												It gets a marginal thumbs up because I got it for 50 cents, it has cards,  and it is what it advertises.   It's a hidden object game with some very rudimentary puzzles baked into it.  You can get perfect achievements with one play through if that's something that drives you. The con to me were slow movement - most of the game is waiting for the bug to move.  I know it's supposed to be atmospheric but with all the back tracking to find things, just a tiny bit more pace to the bug would have made it more enjoyable.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												It's a hidden object game that's very different from most games in this genre.Gameplay-wise this is very similar to Tiny Bang Story but it's much better - the objects are not so difficult to find and hints recharge automatically. Part of the game is also figuring out what to do, there are no tasks or instructions, not even for puzzle mini-games. I usually don't like this but here it's ok.And the game has fantastic music and almost mystical atmosphere. Graphics are ok, animations could have been better.Note: 5€ price tag is a bit high for such a short and simple game. I recommend waiting for a sale.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												It's something strange, non-understandable and... beautiful... that's for sure.With a sign "What a hell!?" on the first level launch... at the finale I had the same question, but different feelings added to the orchestra.Greatly drawn living backgrounds, relaxing music, quite challengable several puzzles (level 4 with crystals - hello:))...I recommend this game for everyone who likes relaxing puzzles.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												Morphopolis is an "art game" if ever there was one.  I say that because I believe for this particular game the art is the priority.  That's not to say there isn't interaction but its gameplay is quite simple.  I'd go as far to say that the gameplay is designed to make sure you focus on and absorb the art.  The eye candy is nice but it takes more then that to design a good game.In Morphopolis you play as different bugs who are kind enough to help out there neighbors with different chores.   Then at the end of each stage it appears you transfer yourself into a larger bug whom you'll play as in the following stage.  There isn't any written story instead the game leaves it up to you to interrupt the meaning behind you're actions.  Even beyond story-telling there isn't even guides to tell you where to go or what to do.  Restricted movement and actions is enough to let you figure out for yourself what you need to accomplish.This game is super stylized.  The consistency of the art work between each stage is spot on.  The stages split across multiple screens which connect seamlessly.  The art is this Morphopolis is stunning.  The paintings are incredible and make you really focus when trying to find the objects you need.  You'll be looking at every little detail as your eyes slowly inspect the image.Essentially, this is a find the objects game.  As you play you'll come across particular plants and bugs that stick out from the backgrounds.  Each of them will ask you to find a set amount of particular items for them.  You'll need to carefully scan the backgrounds and gather up all the items.  Then proceed to deliver them in order to clear a path or initiate a special mini-game puzzle.  All the puzzles are very different and I believe this is were Morphopolis loses it consistency.  Until this point the game is fairly easy and relaxing but a couple of the puzzles are incredibly challenging.  This very bizarre difficulty curve takes you out of what is otherwise an immersive and enjoyable game.Very stylized and original, the only thing holding this game back from is it's struggle balancing.  If you think this might be a game you'll enjoy don't let that hold you back.  That being said I'm sure some people will really enjoy that added challenge.  Those who are worried about getting frustrated can always minimize the game a bring up walk-through for the really tough puzzles.  As I said before art is at the core of this game.  This is an array of visual stimulation that will let you relax and lose yourself in the world.  Look else where for a more interactive and more traditional "game like" experience.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												A gorgeous little time-waster of a game. Art is lush and vibrant; excellent hand-drawn work. The music is soothing and very "zen". Gameplay progresses slowly in that you need to move your insect to and fro different screens and the movement process does get a little clunky, yet the slow and relaxing pace of the game compounds with the superb art and music to create a game that all in all is an excellent choice for unwinding and resting to. Very rejuvenating.Puzzles scattered throughout the game's five stages ensure that you need to at least think and brainstorm a bit to progress. While the lack of instructions can be confusing, once figured out the puzzles are novel and well-designed adaptations of widely-known brain teasers a la beautiful artwork.In summary a fine point-and-click game for relaxing to, yet puzzles make sure that you at least work your brain a little. Recommended for anyone in need of a time killer; if not convinced due to the price just know that you are paying for some of the most beautiful art you will ever see in a game. :)

Posted: August 24, 2015
												Morphopolis is a non-traditional hidden object adventure that is more about mood, balance, and aesthetics than your more garden variety story and character driven gaming experience.  Artwork and innovation are its strong points from the beautifully hand drawn look to the unusual tasks you go about setting nature right.  Although slightly frustrating controls and sorely lacking tutorials make the game a little confusing at points, it is still a development achievement in its own right.  I recommend Morphopolist for it for someone who wants to try something unusual and those who are diehard adventure completionists, while those who are easily frustrated or confused should stay clear.

Posted: January 13
												Cute game, I brought it within a bundle for like 30$c but even at 1$c is fair. I let my girlfriend play it, she is not a gamer so it was an easy way to approach her to gaming.In this point and click adventure you will play as different kind of insects, starting from the smallest to the biggest, the game is divided in 5 chapters and each of them has 4-5 screens where you will collect items in order to proceed.The graphic is colourful and full of details, that's the game strong point.The game doesn't offer much explanations but as soon as you click around randomly you will know what to do.The puzzles are not too hard but some people might be stuck in one or two.The game is quite short and in 1h30 or 2h you can beat it and get all the achievements, however, that's fine if related to the price.When you will move from a screen to another the transition will cause your insect to move until the animation is over, sometimes that can be boring if you move to the other screen for mistake.If you want to spend an hour or two in relax take it, it also gives you steam cards so you can basically have it for free if discounted!

Posted: August 28, 2016
												Overall I loved this game. It was not to long. The puzzles were difficult but not impossible, and they were satisfying. The game's art is beautiful and has a unique style put into it. It can be difficult to guide your bug through the levels, and it can be difficult to find 13 small berries on a 3 stage map, but it just took time and a little concentration. At times the game was easy and repetitive, but the different places that the bug went and the different puzzles and things to do kept it mostly entertaining. I would reccommend this game to anyone who likes getting perfect achievement games, likes great art, slow relaxing games, or just wants to try it. If you pick it up in a winter/summer sale or during one of its' better sales it is only .49 cents in the U.S.A. so I do not believe it is not worth the money.

Posted: March 6
												Morphopolis Review - Raymond KTOne of the most relaxing, short but cheap indie games I have ever played. It has a beautiful art design and the music is exactly what you need for this type of game. It's not a particularly hard game, maybe you get stuck once or twice but overall it's a relaxing and fun experience. I enjoyed Morphopolis. It's a casual game, where you solve puzzles and find hidden items within the vibrant magnified insect world (kindof like "A Bug's Life") . The music is very good - soothing. (My wife wanted the sountrack - so we looked up the composer online). I enjoyed the artwork also - visually the game is pleasing to look at. It's not a particularly hard game - maybe 1 or 2 puzzles that might cause you to think a bit, but overall it's more of an engaging but pleasant and relaxing experience. The controls caused me to get stuck once or twice (there's a puzzle on level 4 where alot of players, like myself, seem to get to and think the game isn't responding because feedback is lacking - but it's a jumping game like checkers). Overall, the game is engaging and doesn't overstay it's welcome. I enjoyed it!

Posted: April 20
												 I don't write alot of reviews, but reading some of the negative reviews on this game compelled me to share some positives.  This is a cute little puzzle and hidden object game.  I really enjoyed the artistic style of the insects and foliage for each scene/level.  I would say this game is a slow moving, relaxing, atmospheric type game.  I played this while sitting in bed and it was perfect just for that.  Some of the puzzles are challenging, but not to the point of being frustrating, and solved them all without using any cheats.  The only problems I had with the game is the lack of a save game option in the middle of the level and also it took me a while to figure out I had to "walk into the light" at the end of the level.  I bought this game on sale and do not regret killing a couple hours with it.

Posted: April 15
												The creators of Morphopolis slowed the game down to make up for it's shortness, meaning that you'll fall asleep five minutes through at this dull gameplay. Also, a glitch in one of the missions caused me to have to restart level 2. So that's pretty much all that needs to be said. Great artwork but a repetitive soundtrack makes the game even more boring.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Morphopolis is a refreshing and relaxing experience, and truly a STUNNING visual masterpiece.Not really difficult, the game can be completed in less than two hours. Short, for sure, however still a good experience, and worth its price especially since it doesn't costs much.There are two types of gameplay in Morphopolis. The first is a point-n'click, where you explore the wonderful backgrounds looking for whatever can be useful. You'll soon have a to-gather list of differents items to use on a particular thing (a bigger bug than yours, a flower...) which will either open you a new path or open a puzzle minigame.These puzzles are the second part of Morphopolis and are as various as a visual memory game, an audio memory game, a "classic" puzzle, a mix-n'-match logical puzzle, and so on.There are two puzzles per level, and five levels in total.The moving system could have been more intuitive and will make you grunt sometimes (by example when you want to go somewhere and end on another panel), but is finally no big deal.The only really annoying thing is that the game doesn't allows you to save your progression while you're in a level, forcing you to restart from scratch the next time.Not the game of the year, but a nicely breath of fresh air.Just avoid it if even 2D bugs make you feel uneasy.

content:

												Would recommend  - according to how one answers this questions.1. Do you like the art style from the screenshots?Yes? Proceed to 2. No? Do not buy.2. No. Wait for sale.It's a nice little game, but very short, and a little bare-bones. (no menu to get out of a minigame screen, had to kill process). It is honestly a very well polished flash game. However the art is so great, and the music so lovely that I think it's worth a few dollars. Maybe not five, but that is up to you.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Lukewarm recommendation, at the price I got it for (25 cents), and even then I'm not sure it's worth the time. At full price it's a waste of money, but at least it has cards and achievements.It's mostly a simple hidden object game and fetch quest, with a few low-rent common puzzles (pipe, jigsaw, slider, etc) that have been seen a million times to draw out the game time. For the most part, the hidden objects are blatant, but I had trouble with some green ones given that there's just so much green everywhere. I didn't see anything original anywhere.It's somewhat pretty, in a 1998 Newgrounds original sort of way, but it certainly isn't awe-inspiring art. Its Flash roots are very obvious. The music is good, in an unmemorable way. The controls are abominably bad, though, requiring you to hold down the mouse button to keep moving and regularly move your mouse around because the pathing is so bad and your bug gets confused. You move at a snail's pace, too. Too bad you don't get to play as one....A much better game in the same vein is Violett. Do yourself a favor and play that instead.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												7.2/10 - Beautifully Artful; Short and StellarThis game is usually really cheap so I recommend it. The art style is one of a kind. There are also puzzles thrown in make you think, but are in no way too difficult to enjoy. Only 5-6 stages on this game so it's pretty short. I'd grab this on sale or in a bundle if possible.Worth $3ish Accidently ReviewedWas this review helpful or maybe even not helpful? Either way join this group for more. Free Keys and Reviews weekly!

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												I thoroughly enjoyed the experience of playing Morphopolis. The concept was pretty straight-forward and the puzzles were stimulating enough without being too over-demanding. I actually found it easy to unwind whilst playing this - the colours and sounds created a soothing effect.Morphopolis was compared somewhere to The Room (another game I loved immensely). My experience of the two games differed in that I completed Morphopolis in one sitting, whilst with The Room I reached several points where I became stuck and had to take a break before resuming.When I played Morphopolis there were  five levels and they didn't take too long to get through. It would be nice if more levels were added or a follow-up released. This is a great game and I highly recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This game only took two hours for me to complete, which made me pay roughly €0.09 per hour, which I got back by gaining three cards which can be sold for roughly €0.2~, buit I would have spent €5 for this game, and here’s why.First off, there’s no real option menu, which annoyed me at first since there’s no way to change the volume nor a real interface. Clearly this is more suited for an iPad where you can sit and relax with just your index finger but I’m so happy that I played it on 1920x1080p since the graphics are amazing. The artstyle is colorful and it helps when it comes to how the puzzles are built, forcing you to admire the artstyle while playing. This game is slowing down the pace, forcing you to actually study the environment in search for clues or hidden key all while listening to a wonderful soundtrack that’s soothing and mysterious at the same time.There’s a downside though, the controls can be clunky and the insect you’re playing is moving so slow which makes it mildly infuriating when it comes to running back and forward when it comes to solving puzzles. Yet, this was an amazing gaming experience, and this is coming from someone who usually ignores the puzzles and ragequit while pretending to be intellectually superior since I haven’t let the game prove me wrong.HIGHLY recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												Morphopolis is a wonderfully beautifull game appearance wise and music wise. The puzzles, although confusing at first where relaxing and wonderfully well creafted. In ceartain areas however, the insect had gotten stuck or got confused on where to go, but it was always something fixable. The game is point and click all the way through and there is a lot of walking the insect through the same areas over and over again. Even so, every time I walked through the space again I would always notice something that I hadn't seen before. Furthermore, allow me to again express how beautifull this game is. It has very original graphics as well as a 3D aspect in some levels. There is also a wide variety of different creatures and plants to look at and interact with. In addition there is different music for each level and each puzzle, and I enjoyed every track. The levels usually took 10-30  minutes to complete but I never got bored of the soundtrack.  I would recommend this game to people who like puzzle games and would like to enjoy a couple of hours of relaxing entertainment.

												Let me start by saying that this is definitely the prettiest Hidden Object game that I have ever played. The graphics are just beautiful to look at and the music is very pleasant. However, I must point out that the interface can be very clunky at times. There are no directions in the game, and no text at all. This can lead to frustration when you don't realize that you could have been double clicking on your character to interact with something, or when you are staring at a puzzle with little or no idea of what you are meant to do... so I don't really recommend this game to anyone that doesn't have the patience to experiment and figure things out on their own. For what I paid, I really did get my money's worth and more.

												This game only took two hours for me to complete, which made me pay roughly €0.09 per hour, which I got back by gaining three cards which can be sold for roughly €0.2~, buit I would have spent €5 for this game, and here’s why.First off, there’s no real option menu, which annoyed me at first since there’s no way to change the volume nor a real interface. Clearly this is more suited for an iPad where you can sit and relax with just your index finger but I’m so happy that I played it on 1920x1080p since the graphics are amazing. The artstyle is colorful and it helps when it comes to how the puzzles are built, forcing you to admire the artstyle while playing. This game is slowing down the pace, forcing you to actually study the environment in search for clues or hidden key all while listening to a wonderful soundtrack that’s soothing and mysterious at the same time.There’s a downside though, the controls can be clunky and the insect you’re playing is moving so slow which makes it mildly infuriating when it comes to running back and forward when it comes to solving puzzles. Yet, this was an amazing gaming experience, and this is coming from someone who usually ignores the puzzles and ragequit while pretending to be intellectually superior since I haven’t let the game prove me wrong.HIGHLY recommend.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												You a bug.This point and click adventure game about being an insect and finding pieces to advance into the levels and fix your friend so you can become them. kind of.5 unique levels as different insects and new areas offers a relaxing time for children and adults looking for a slow, stress relieving game. This game has ambient music and pretty, colourly art that lightens up the game. Remember: If you leave anywhere in a level without completing it, you will need to start over. There are no checkpoints.The game is simple to play, relatively straightforward (some instructions are missing which slowed down gameplay even further) and has 8 puzzles of different skill levels (4 easy / 1 normal / 3 hard)It has a decent help system with a button you can press for the next objectives location that recharges over time. Sometimes instructions are no clear and will leave you guessing and clicking everything on screen to get to the next location. The game can feel like it takes forever due to the slow game progression and the constant walking between zones. Negative or positive I leave that up to you.Puzzles are not explained very well, so some of them can be hard or difficult not because of the puzzle itself but the lack of information going into the task.Its a nice relaxing, colourful artsy puzzle game for the child at heart. It's only 1$ and has about 2 hours of gameplay.Personal Rating: 3/5

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Beautiful hidden-object game with limited gameplay4/10 ★★★★★★☆☆☆☆GameplayMorphopolis needs some decent mechanics despretly. What's there instead of it at the moment is not only basic, but contrasts with stunning aesthetics painfully. Gameplay is constrained to basic movement along fixed routes, clicking here and there, and a few simple puzzles. It is not enough, even for a game not aiming at providing challange, but relax.PresentationThe game is bueatiful. Backgrounds are detailed, full of vivid colors, well-drawn. It is a feast to the eyes; a feast, which cries: I'm ready to please gamers - when the gameplay is about to arrive?Audio is matching and competent, but a mere backgroud for the graphics.Summing upEmpty shell - great graphics with extremely limited gameplay.positive beatutiful relaxingnegative extremely limited gameplay repetitivness short zero replayabilityAesthetic experience - not a game. Cannot recommend.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I recommend this game only for people looking to get an easy 100% achievement game and some trading cards.  I got it for $0.24, and at that price it was worth it to me for the achievements and the cards.This is a fairly easy puzzle game.  There was only one puzzle (the last one) that I considered difficult.  I found the controls for moving my insect (point and click with mouse) to be annoying.  Most of the time you are looking for hidden objects on the screen.  After finding the required objects on each level, there is then a puzzle or two to move on.  There are five levels.  It's very casual, there are no real risks or ways to mess anything up.  You just keep trying until you find the objects or solve the puzzle.  Maybe about 2 hours of total gameplay for 100% achievements, possibly longer if you get stuck on some of the puzzles.

												First off, let me preface this by saying that I don't normally take the time to write a review unless I feel strongly about a game, and this one definitely has that covered. I just can't sit here and let anyone else fall into the ratings trap that this game is.This game is fun for about the first five minutes. From then on it becomes infuriatingly slow, tedious, and downright annoying. On top of that it has pretty much no playability, it took me just over an hour (it felt like five) to complete this game and get all of the achievements. Even after i have beaten the game and have literally nothing else to do on it, it didn't even drop me one of the trading cards. In short, there are plenty of things you could spend your money on instead of this game, like a soda, or a candy bar, or just throwing your money into the garbage. I would never recommend this game to anyone and now that I am through with it, I will never touch this game again, not even to try for the card drops.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												Got this on sale for 50 cents.I think 50 cents or so would of been a fair price for what I got, but I still can't reccomend it based on the price tag and content alone.If you're really bad at puzzles, the game might take you an hour at most.It took me about 20-30 minutes to beat this game however.Achievements didn't work right away though so I had to beat it 2 more times.The only really hard puzzle for those who have never done them before is the beatle puzzle.It's not as hard as it looks however as you're really just swapping out things in order till it's in the order you need it in.Bottom line is though.1. Not enough content for what it is.2. Puzzles are too easy.3. Music cannot be muted4. 2 dollars for 20 minutes of content with 0 replayability.If you snag a discount card and can snag it for under a dollar, and you like puzzle games with some atmosphere, then I would get it.It's got steam cards as well too so there is that.But even then you'll play it once and never looks back.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												I didn't like this game at all. I am a puzzle loving gamer, but that did not make any sense at all. The puzzles were too hard and you couldn't get hints. Also, it seems that if you try for a long period of time to solve something, at some point the game will let you go through as if you solved the puzzle. It is bad because the developers are admitting that the puzzles are too hard and badly designed, and good because finally I could finish this game. Other than that, I did not like the fact that I had to press all the time on a spot for the character to move to it. The path you should take is not clear, which is fine, but it is not supported by the game. In case you have a place you shouldn't go, your carecter will go that way and get "stuck" going back and forth "polinating" the area. The "action" option is redundant in some stages, so shouldn't appear at all in them, there is simply no point. The character moves too slow and it's annoying when your area of exploration is so limited and frustrating like I mentioned.I did like the art and the music was good. Sounds were nice, but that's about it. There is much, so much more that could have been done in this game to improve it. Too bad it didn't happen.

												Атмосферная и очень красивая игра, которую можно пройти менее чем за час, но этому препятствует ряд недоработок. В целом игра стоит потраченного времени.Главная её проблема это откровенно слабый геймдизайн - многие вещи слабо очевидны в плане механики, что вынуждает производить слишком много "научного тыка". Складывается впечатление, что игру кроме самого разработчка и его кошки никто не тестировал. Второй проблемой является непосредственное управление персонажем. Тут сказывается "привет" от мобильных платформ: залипания, вяленькая отзывчивость, недостаточная очевидность доступного маршрута. Третьей проблемой является критическая ошибка r6010 при старте игры (на момент 14.04.2015). РЕШЕНИЕ: ЗАПУСКАЙТЕ project.exe В РЕЖИМЕ СОВМЕСТИМОСТИ Win98/ME.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Other reviews of this game have stated that Morphopolis is better as a work of art than a game, but I have to disagree because having bought primarily for the aesthetic of it I found out very quickly that this fails as both a game and as an art project.First, throughout the game there are huge lags in frame rate, which I initially thought was just part of the trippy look of the whole thing, then I thought it was a problem with my computer. But nope, I can run Skyrim with no drop in frame rate on my laptop but this simplistic thing jarrs just by having your insect change direction or if there are too much stuff going on in a particular level.The art work that made me buy the game in the first place quickly became irritating the more I played, the style is not well integrated into the gameplay at all, the title screen made the animation look fluid but when playing the game you often just have your legs animated while they drag your whole immovable body through the levels, the same type of animation cheats they use on most of the non-playable insects and environments, making the whole experience look clumpy and ugly.The controls are equally awkward, you don't use wasd keys because I guess that would not be “arty” enough for the developers, you have to hold the left mouse button in the direction you want to go and there's a 50% chance you might actually get there if you don't have to find something to click on to solve a tiresome puzzle. Most of my playthrough was spent just trying to get my bug in the right direction so that I could crawl on a narrow route through invisible walls just to collect foliage to open the next level. Only to find I had to backtrack to collect a different set of items to actually move on, if they had individual puzzles open every time I had to do this that might have been barely tolerable, many times it's just busy work to pad the game.I spent on average more than 20 minutes doing this alone nearly every level, this is already a short game and most of playing it is navigating nonsensical pre-determined pathways that made me want to kick my laptop into the ocean, if it wasn't through my stubbornness and the promise of achievements and trading cards I would have given up much earlier. The hidden object portion of Morphopolis is really difficult, and not in a challenging or clever way, just in a frustrating eye-squinting way. This is where the art work really works against game, the objects you need often blend too well into the background or are so small you really have to get close to the screen to truly see them, or you have to access them by clicking the bug you control at a specific time, I only found this out through randomly clicking everything in sight and looking at let's plays, the game does not give you any of this information. Most of the levels are a homogeneous mass of art, which would be fine if it was just a very detailed background for a different kind of game, as something you have to slog through in order to complete the game it's a sickening and confusing mess that I tired of very quickly.Which brings me to the puzzles, you don't get much help in this game, that's not necessarily a bad thing, but it is if finding the hidden objects you need often comes down to clicking everywhere and hoping you get what you need, looking through a walkthrough (where many of the let's players seemed just as lost as I was), or hitting the hint button which straight up tells you where objects are but only when it's charged up and when you're in the right area. Can't find how to access the area you need to be in through the invisible walls? Hint button not fully charged until the next minute? Well tough, you have to wait for the hint button to charge and if no hints are available just wonder about hoping that you can reach where you need to be by clicking on anything, maybe the game will help you find how to complete the level, maybe it won't, maybe you'll figure it out through trial and error, you probably won't, there is no merciful god here.And while we're on the subject, “immersion” does not mean slow and ponderous, being “arty” doesn't mean just plodding through weird surroundings with a weird non-story, you can't layer your game with arty visuals and call it immersive without any further effort on story, character or playability. While I'm sure many defenders of this game found it beautiful and meaningful, I and many others were praying for a skip button or any kind of save feature where we didn't have to go at a snails pace through the same level over and over again because we had the audacity to want to do stuff we enjoyed or look up a guide. Even an option to get out of some of puzzle modes so you can come back to it later or save so you don't have to repeat everything up until that point would have been a logical thing for this game to have, but I guess functionality doesn't win you illustrator awards so that isn't a feature. If the game wasn't so short it would be completely unplayable because of this, as it is it just makes the game annoying.This game even fails to do a jigsaw puzzle properly, the art style while pretty (depending on taste) made what should have been a straightforward jigsaw puzzle into a frustrating rage game. Some of the pieces simply did not look like they were supposed to fit, lumps and bumps that were on pieces slotted perfectly into smoother areas, if it wasn't through a process of elimination I doubt I could have solved the puzzle. If this was unintentional then the developers cannot even develop the simplest puzzle with their art style properly, if it was intentional all it did was baffle me and frustrate me further, either way it made what should have been a beautiful game into an ugly experience. This isn't “challenging”, some of the puzzles fundamentally don't follow reasonable rules, there is no skill involved in these, only guesswork and irritation.I simply did not care what was going on by level 4, there was no incentive to fully complete level 5 for me, Morphopolis gave me no investment in the gameplay, the story (what little it has) and what few characters we see (if you can call them that since we know nothing about these insects and we can't know anything about them because “art”). I wasn't relaxed or charmed, I was bored and angry, even if the game's conclusion was so mind-blowing that it completely made all the flaws I found in it meaningful I simply cannot muster any energy to give a damn about it at this point. As a further insult, the achievements feel hollow because they are awarded for just the level and puzzle completions, no easter eggs or prizes for additional effort seem to be on offer, and the trading card drops for me were only available towards the end of the game and are worth squat on the market.This isn't what a puzzle game should be, this isn't what a hidden object game should be, and it is not what an art game should be. It failed to be good at any of these things, and even though I spent less than 50p on it at the time I still feel ripped off, the developers should feel incredibly lucky to have gotten a positive rating for this.

Posted: November 23, 2015
												Other reviews of this game have stated that Morphopolis is better as a work of art than a game, but I have to disagree because having bought primarily for the aesthetic of it I found out very quickly that this fails as both a game and as an art project.First, throughout the game there are huge lags in frame rate, which I initially thought was just part of the trippy look of the whole thing, then I thought it was a problem with my computer. But nope, I can run Skyrim with no drop in frame rate on my laptop but this simplistic thing jarrs just by having your insect change direction or if there are too much stuff going on in a particular level.The art work that made me buy the game in the first place quickly became irritating the more I played, the style is not well integrated into the gameplay at all, the title screen made the animation look fluid but when playing the game you often just have your legs animated while they drag your whole immovable body through the levels, the same type of animation cheats they use on most of the non-playable insects and environments, making the whole experience look clumpy and ugly.The controls are equally awkward, you don't use wasd keys because I guess that would not be “arty” enough for the developers, you have to hold the left mouse button in the direction you want to go and there's a 50% chance you might actually get there if you don't have to find something to click on to solve a tiresome puzzle. Most of my playthrough was spent just trying to get my bug in the right direction so that I could crawl on a narrow route through invisible walls just to collect foliage to open the next level. Only to find I had to backtrack to collect a different set of items to actually move on, if they had individual puzzles open every time I had to do this that might have been barely tolerable, many times it's just busy work to pad the game.I spent on average more than 20 minutes doing this alone nearly every level, this is already a short game and most of playing it is navigating nonsensical pre-determined pathways that made me want to kick my laptop into the ocean, if it wasn't through my stubbornness and the promise of achievements and trading cards I would have given up much earlier. Most of the levels are a homogeneous mass of art, which would be fine if it was just a very detailed background for a different kind of game, as something you have to slog through in order to complete the game it's a sickening and confusing mess that I tired of very quickly.Which brings me to the puzzles, you don't get much help in this game, that's not necessarily a bad thing, but it is if finding the hidden objects you need often comes down to clicking everywhere and hoping you get what you need, looking through a walkthrough (where many of the let's players seemed just as lost as I was), or hitting the hint button which straight up tells you where objects are but only when it's charged up and when you're in the right area. Can't find how to access the area you need to be in through the invisible walls? Hint button not fully charged until the next minute? Well tough, you have to wait for the hint button to charge and if no hints are available just wonder about hoping that you can reach where you need to be by clicking on anything, maybe the game will help you find how to complete the level, maybe it won't, maybe you'll figure it out through trial and error, you probably won't, there is no merciful god here.And while we're on the subject, “immersion” does not mean slow and ponderous, being “arty” doesn't mean just plodding through weird surroundings with a weird non-story, you can't layer your game with arty visuals and call it immersive without any further effort on story, character or playability. While I'm sure many defenders of this game found it beautiful and meaningful, I and many others were praying for a skip button or any kind of save feature where we didn't have to go at a snails pace through the same level over and over again because we had the audacity to want to do stuff we enjoyed or look up a guide. Even an option to get out of some of puzzle modes so you can come back to it later or save so you don't have to repeat everything up until that point would have been a logical thing for this game to have, but I guess functionality doesn't win you illustrator awards so that isn't a feature. If the game wasn't so short it would be completely unplayable because of this, as it is it just makes the game annoying.This game even fails to do a jigsaw puzzle properly, the art style while pretty (depending on taste) made what should have been a straightforward jigsaw puzzle into a frustrating rage game. Some of the pieces simply did not look like they were supposed to fit, lumps and bumps that were on pieces slotted perfectly into smoother areas, if it wasn't through a process of elimination I doubt I could have solved the puzzle. If this was unintentional then the developers cannot even develop the simplest puzzle with their art style properly, if it was intentional all it did was baffle me and frustrate me further, either way it made what should have been a beautiful game into an ugly experience. This isn't “challenging”, some of the puzzles fundamentally don't follow reasonable rules, there is no skill involved in these, only guesswork and irritation.I simply did not care what was going on by level 4, there was no incentive to fully complete level 5 for me, Morphopolis gave me no investment in the gameplay, the story (what little it has) and what few characters we see (if you can call them that since we know nothing about these insects and we can't know anything about them because “art”). I wasn't relaxed or charmed, I was bored and angry, even if the game's conclusion was so mind-blowing that it completely made all the flaws I found in it meaningful I simply cannot muster any energy to give a damn about it at this point. As a further insult, the achievements feel hollow because they are awarded for just the level and puzzle completions, no easter eggs or prizes for additional effort seem to be on offer, and the trading card drops for me were only available towards the end of the game and are worth squat on the market.This isn't what a puzzle game should be, this isn't what a hidden object game should be, and it is not what an art game should be. 												Snagged this guy on sale for only $0.24. Beautiful, hand-drawn graphics and peaceful music. The puzzle gameplay kept me going til the end. The mechanics are a little whacko at times, which kinda makes maneuvering a little clunky. Overall good game though. I would've paid more for it. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												This game is amazing.It's not the kind you usually see on Steam. It's usually either hat simulators or rock simulators, so seeing something so artistic was new. The art in this game is beautiful, and so is the music. I would honestly pay for an OST also. The game has a cute, melancholy feel to it, and the art and music are very fitting with each other. It's essentially a hidden object game, but there's also some puzzles and point and click. The gameplay is hard enough to keep it a challenge, but easy enough to make it casual and fun.The one downfall this game has is the shortness of it. I've beaten the game in my playtime, which is 2.5 hours. (Well, almost. I kind of ragequit on that last puzzle, but I'll beat it later lol.) I'm not sure if the price is worth it. The art, music, and gameplay is tremendous, but the shortness is kind of upsetting. Hopefully there's a sequel or update in the future.So overall, yes. I do recommend this game, even for the original price. But, if it is on sale, buy it, because it's a steal. (I got it for 24 cents.)

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												I'm a bit disappointed, but that's mainly because of my mistake.I've watched only the first half of the trailer, and so I've assumed it was some sort of platformer, while it really is just a glorified hidden object game.However, while it has no plot to speak of, a rather limited gameplay (which is often the case with this genre,) and a very short length (which may actually be a good thing, because this sort of game would get tedious after a while,) it may be one of the better hidden object games, to my limited knowledge at least, for the refreshing and unique hand-drawn visuals alone. So at the very least, it has that going for it.If you're a fan of hidden object games, give this one a try.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												Morphopolis is a beautiful and very short hidden-object game with some puzzles of various levels of difficulty. There is no real story, but rather a sequence of scenes that more-or-less overlap with an insect's life.As you can see from the screenshots, it is a delight to behold! Just be aware that, unfortunately, it is also frustrating to play: the controls are terrible, as you move very slowly and it's too easy to move to the next screen by mistake. Luckily, the game is short enough that the frustration will soon end.Also, note that the final puzzle is devilishly hard. Because it's randomized, there is no single walkthrough that would work for everyone. You have to understand it the old-fashioned way and patiently figure it out!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												If you want to run this on a PC with a mouse, good luck.There are no instructions.There are no settings. You cannot control resolution, windowed mode, and so on.There are no controls, effectively. You're supposed to click and hold to make the caterpillar move. It'll do that a little, but you'll get stuck at some point and wherever it is that you're supposed to click and hold to make it move again is completely, utterly, counter-intuitive.I'm uninstalling before full-on nerdrage kicks in.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												A brief puzzle game for the patient.If you've played and enjoyed Tiny Bang Story, you will most likely enjoy Morphopolis. While controlling an insect, you retrieve a certain number of certain objects for certain taskgivers whether they be other insects or plants. The game in all takes maybe around 30-40 minutes. This 30-40 minutes can easily be filled with relaxation for this breed of game has its calming effects with its soothing music and simple find-the-things gameplay. However, if you are not the most patient person, you may not enjoy this game due to the slow movement speed of the insect that you control to move through different parts of a level. When you know what you are to do, you complete the task in a matter of seconds. It takes just as long, if not longer, to move between the different sections to progress.Overall, if you are patient and want a low-stress game to occupy yourself for under an hour, I would reccomend Tiny Bang Story, but this would come soon after.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Morphopolis is beautiful, occasionally frustrating, and short.What I liked:Gorgeous artworkMore gorgeous artwork (it deserves to be mentioned twice)Fairly original conceptEnjoyable mini puzzlesWhat distracted from my enjoyment:Bug movement issues: I would occasionally get my bug stuck on something and be unable to move it.  Alternatively, sometimes it would interpret an attempt to click on anything, anywhere on the screen as a command to move to the screen above if I were near the top edge.  Also by the end of the game, I found I was impatient with the speed my bug moved.  Apparently it had crossbred with a snail somewhere in there.At least one minipuzzle needs to be a little more dynamic so players can figure out how it works faster.  It took me about ten minutes to figure out that I was supposed to click and drag pebbles, partially because when I tried clicking and dragging there was no feedback or indication that it was working.  (10 minutes to figure out to click and drag.  Maybe 2 minutes to solve.  Meh.)It's short.  Really short.  Five chapters short.  I'm a very slow, stare-at-and-enjoy-the-scenery kind of gamer and I finished it in 3.5 hours.  (Confession time: the final puzzle took me 1.5 hours.  I'm terrible at those.)  There's also very little replay value except to look at the art.Recommended?On sale? Yes. Definitely.Regularly priced?  This depends on how highly you value creativity, puzzles, art, replay value, etc.  Personally, the art helps, but I need a longer game to justify full price.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The art is interesting but the gameplay leaves quite a bit to be desired.  The few puzzles in the game are not very challenging and much of the game is spent searching for the paths you can walk along.  That was more challenging than finding the barely hidden objects.  Then when you do find the paths, the bug moves very slowly along them, and you have to click and hold while it crawls or it stops.  That combined with the bug's tendancy to end up on the wrong path and get caught in battles against your mouse at path junctions makes the game extremely frustrating.  Were is not for the mechanics issues, this would be a 30 minute game.  As is, it drags into an hour and a half+ game with a questionable story that suggests the authors had an intersting concept for the bug world, but it was never articulated beyond "The bug eats things and disguises itself."  Again, good concept, nice art, but the game part of the game was not well executed and I see zero replay value in it.  Considering the generally positive reviews, this game was a let down for me.
