content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												In Morphopolis, you play a sort of microscopic parisitic intelligence that seeks progressively larger corpses to inhabit and animate, which is a very cool concept.  You accomplish this by painstakingly crawling your zombie bug of the moment around a few few screens of a fantastical insect realm, all drawn in a psychedelic art style, clicking on a lot of not-particularly-hidden objects and playing a couple of minigames.You may at first find that the game is very, horribly slow, but understand that this is your fault, gamer.  Just because Morphopolis was described as a "game," you thought that it would be something you could "play," while having "fun" and worst of all, maybe even "win" it.  Those are your preconceptions and they are wrong, wrong, wrong!  Morphopolis is not a game to play, it is a game to experience!  See the fantastical setting?  You didn't see it enough!  An artist went to a lot of work to draw those environments, and you will look at them properly!  Your avatar will keep crossing back into previous screens, where you didn't intend to go, just to ensure that you have properly appreciated the art!  The object-collecting quests will send you creeping back and forth again and again, so you will spend sufficient time staring at the art to demonstrate proper respect.Hear the beautiful, trippy soundtrack?  No!  You weren't paying sufficient attention, what with your gameplayer attitude of rushing through looking for enemies to kill and goals to accomplish!  The developers will helpfully correct you by slowing everything down to the pace of a slug crawling through wet cement, to ensure that you have the time to correctly appreciate the music!There are also no instructions, other than some pictograms, which sometimes makes the nature of the game a bit unclear -- that was to make the experience more immersive, and not in any way a cheap trick for saving money on localization.So don't play Morphopolis, experience it.  It has beautiful art and sound.  If you were expecting to have fun, well, that's your selfish attitude.  Shame on you.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												Would I recommend this game? Whenever the price drops for a while again, then yes, especially if you feel charmed by the look of the game. However everything above 2 Euro would seem too much pricy n my opinion... Here's why: Pro: * the artful drawings and likable meditation-inducing piano-sound give off a very nice and enjoyable atmosphere* this game is in reality a Hidden Object Game - search for half-hidden stuff in 2D-sceneries filled to the rim with details and in between play a number of different minigames. Which is great in my opinion because I love HOGs. Well, if you don't, that might not be a Plus for you then...* if you have ever played a bunch of HOGs, you will immediately recognize the minigames and will know what you have to do, as they are all very typical and not too hard to solve* Morphopolis also has elements of an adventure as you have to "control" an insect and make it crawl around a bit plus you'll have to click on some cratures or plants to "hand in" stuff you've found/collected. But this is very little adventure-like gameplay all in all, much less than most modern HOGs feature actually. Not even as much "adventure" as in Botanicula or Samorost, although Morphopolis might make you think of games like that instinctivelyContra:* the game is extremely short. E.x.t.r.e.m.e.l.y. I finished it within 2 hours, which included a coffee-break. To be more precisely: Morphopolis only has 5 "chapters", consisting of 17 screens/scenes and 7 minigames in total (if I did not miscalculate). I really wonder why it has to be so short? It couldn't have been so hard to add many more sceneries, more stuff to collect, and perhaps also more of the re-usable types of minigames - especially the beautiful butterfly jigsaw or the "plant repair"-game. Did the developers just lose interest all of a sudden whilst making the game, or did they have a fight and decided to stop working together instantly?* if Morphopolis was just a point-and-click-game I would have finished it within 1 hour. But the developers had this "brilliant" *coughs* idea to make the game "last longer" by letting your insectoid avatar crawl only very, very slowly. Painfully slowly :( * the controls add to your discomfort - the way how to move and where to move your insect are horribly rigid. It does not help much that by clicking and holding your left mouse button on the insect it will emit dark greenish ... uh... I really think it looks like dung ... to give a hint about possible paths it can take next within a close radius* it takes a lot of patience to make your insect go where you want it to, but then you make one wrong click and your insect will quickly switch to the next/former screen even if you didn't want that -_-* in chapter two your insect has to eat/suck three egglike things, which you can only find out by sheer luck like by clicking around wildly and hitting one of the eggs per chance. And there's this one minigame in chapter 5 where you have to "swipe" with the cursor to let a small heap of seeds "jump" over others. It took me quite a while and luck to find out how to move these piles of seed :( No explanations for the controls to be found for minigames anywhere. Is this supposed to be "part of the fun"? Well, not for me, sorry.* you also cannot skip any minigames, which can be really frustrating for some people. Well, but if you could, then the game would be over in the blink of an eye; so I guess that's why you can't... Pity.* for an Hidden Object Game the stuff you have to find is not "hidden" well nor cleverly. Sometimes it is nearly invisible, which will make you click wildly all over your screen after a while - that will do the trick, but will leave you unsatisfied. With this kind of interesting, detailled and colorful background, blending stuff in could have been done 100 times better* the "story" about transformation lacks a bit too in my opinion, as in three levels the "goal" of your insect is to meet with a much larger insect and seemingly to dig into it's head, which does not make much sense... Conclusion: there are many beautiful hand-drawn artistic games with relaxing music and interesting ideas out there. Morphopolis definitely has the potential to be a real gem of this genre. But it turned out to be a mere sherd. Makes me want to replay Botanicula and sing along with the frogs ;)

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
  Buzz Kill   You'd expect to find this game in a Natural History museum, attracting kids like they were flies to its sticky touchscreen.The parents are happy that they have a free moment to themselves as their children get absorbed in educational software.The kids know that they're not going to learn anything. They get frustrated with the terrible touchscreen controls but they keep playing because there is nothing better to do in the museum. Where did the Murderer hide all the body parts?  You might have seen the "point and click" tag, but Morphopolis is actually a hidden object game. You are an insect and you wander around 2D backdrops looking for specific objects to unlock the next search.These can be either plants, eggs or - quite interestingly - dismembered insect parts.The BGM, which can be described as ambient-easy-listening, might feel relaxing to some although it felt a bit dull to me, not to mention that the game has some annoying jingles everytime you complete a riddle (just like the sound jingle from the edusoft at the museum!).The art style is beautiful, some luxuriously detailed 2D backdrops of nature, vegetation, and insects. The problem is you have to wander back and forth between those screens repeatedly each level...and because you are slow it gets tedious.The game also throws 1 or 2 random one-screen puzzles each level. Those range from okay to very boring. Drags are bad! Mmmhk?  So far it's pretty much a mixed bag, but this is where the recommendation stops.This is a lazy mobile port. Terribly lazy. The control scheme is just criminal. It's beyond awful.You might have noticed the "point and click" tag but Morphopolis is actually a "point and drag" or should i say a "drag and drag".The only way to move your insect is to drag the mouse across the screen. Constantly. You don't just click where you want it to go, you don't use WASD, you just drag, and drag and draaaaaaag. Each 15 minute level is 14 minutes of your finger solidly pressed against the left mouse button. Not even on my phone  Did I mention the insect moves at 2 kilometers per millenium? Or that the pathing is pretty fiddly?Not only can you instantly feel that the game is made for a touchscreen,  you can also instantly feel that even if you played it on touchscreen the controls would still be frustrating For one of the puzzles, I had to resort to google - not to find a solution, but just to figure out how the damn controls work! I cannot recommend this game, for its carpal tunnel syndrome inducing control scheme. Save it for the kids at the museum, and go find your insect murder mystery fun some place else.

												?/? - morphine comes to mindThe late film critic Roger Ebert once refused to rate "The Human Centipede". He kind of felt that as a movie it was unbearable but that maybe the author/director was only using the medium film to make a statement, that maybe it was art  - and art is nothing that a film critic could judge.I am kind of in the same place now. As a game it is a complete fail in my opinion - but maybe it's some weird kind of art, or a Zen statement, or maybe it's meant as an animated music video, or maybe it's the "Lucy in the Sky" for PC games - honestly I have no clue.All I know, is that I would NOT recommend it to the 'regular' gamer that makes up 99% of the Steam user base.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Bought the game for the art style, and on that it delivers. In all other aspects though, it really doesn't.You control a bug that goes from larvae to some form of avian insect reminiscent of a bumblebee. To do this you crawl (very slowly) from screen to screen through out five short chapters, collecting objects to manipulate the world in different ways. This part is pretty much a hidden objects-game. Sometimes when you have collected all the parts for one of the objectives you are rewarded with a small puzzle. These puzzles aren't anything special. The difficulty of the puzzles are for the most part trivial, but I got stuck twice because of a couple of very misleading or unintuitive elements. And that is all there is to it.I paid 0,19€ for it, and for that price I think it's worth a play through just for the art. For the regular asking price though, I would not recommend it, for that price I'd expect more game for my money.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												I am utterly shocked that this game has received such high reviews.   This is a point and click with a different sort of artsy backdrop of bugs and plants.  The artistry is nice, but it really stops there.  I really tried to like this game and even completed it, hoping for some redeeming value.  getting the bug to move from screen to screen was tedious, having to go back to old screens to collect items you weren't allowed to collect originally (even knowing it would be necessary later), and having to figure out what you were to do on each screen became monotonous. And the bug was SLOW.  getting the puzzles to start was also slow (the lightening bugs, for example).  There was a good 15 second delay.  Does not seem like much in the scheme of things, but just sit there waiting to understand what the game is doing, and it seems like an eternity.By the end of the game, when I wasn't sure what was next, my thought was, "it had better not make me go through all of the screens on this level to collect the water drops.  If it does, its over!"  It did not, thankfully, but that did not make the game any more fun.  There is no guide, except a little question mark in the upper right corner to "help" you when you are stuck.  But, it does not always help you.  It ONLY helps when looking for a collectable item and it is on the page you are on, otherwise it gongs.  If there is another step (a branch, for instance) it does not help you find it.  Time was wasted on trying to figure out what the many puzzles wanted.  Once I understood them, it was fine, but it was not intuitive.My final though was, "did I really spend money on this game?"  I bought it on sale, but, that does not make me any happier.  I buy most of my games based on the very positive ratings they receive.  I would not pay money for this game unless I were a point and click collector.  There are plenty of other point and clicks (even free) that are much more enjoyable.  The two hours I lost on the game were not enjoyable ones.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												I should have known a game that looks like an ugly handbag couldn't play well. The controlls are awful, with your insect turning around and going back if you overshoot slightly, or, as it was for me, every single time I tried to move somewhere, at least twice. It's very hard to know where you can go, what to do next, what you're supposed to be hunting, if the irational rage you suddenly feel towards women and insects says more about the game or you... It's a lot of uncertainty to handle, too much for the hints system to address. I got stuck in the second level when the full gamut of places I knew how to access contained no hints, and had to rage-quit. the absence of mid-level saves has a silver lining, in at least excusing my refusal to return to the game.Basically it was awful and I'm proud of myself to managing to review it without swearing. I did get it for 19p in the sale, so you would think I would be able to contain my anger.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

												4/10+++ It's a puzzle game with challenging puzzles, which is good an worth it's price if you like puzzles. would rate it 4/10 because of that, but:--- horrible controlls--- character moves annoyingly slow- the game could be cleared in half the time (about 45-60mins instead of 120mins) if the character would move faster and if the controlls were better-- I dont like the art style very much and I dont like insects- boring story (haha, there is none: solve riddles, crawl inside a giant insect, repeat x5)- unsatisfiying ending (crawl inside a cave)

Posted: July 13, 2015
												"Morphopolis", or "A Bug's Life", is a short hidden object game with slight point-and-click elements, mainly in directing your character, which is a bug, by pointing and clicking. The bug grows from larvae to bigger buggy forms, while collecting hidden items and solving occasional puzzles.The game features 5 stages, a soothing soundtrack, beautiful artwork, sluggish and unresponsive controls, and a frustrating last puzzle which may take you minutes or hours to complete, based on your luck. I was lucky and finished it in about 10 minutes, completely by accident.Since I got it for €0.19 on sale, I consider it money well spent. At its full price of €4.99, eh, not so much. Beautiful audio-visuals aside, the core gameplay is really boring and at times frustrating because,(a) the bug moves really slowly, and(b) the boundaries of the playable area and paths to take are often not clearly visible.All in all, expect some 1.5 - 3 hrs of playtime, with no replay value. Overall, OK, but "Would not morph into a cricket again," to use the lame review trope.

Posted: July 20, 2015
												Pros:Just from the screenshots it is obvious the game is stunning. It has an art style that sucks you in. The game mixes point and click, hidden object, and easy puzzle solving. There are 5 levels that you progress through and in each one you expereince the world as a different bug. It is a really orginal and fun idea. Cons:The controls take a little getting used to. I was so frustrated in level one that I almost quit. That was the only level I had issues moving the bug. It gets easier. The price. I am not sure that I would have loved the game so much if I had payed full price. I got the game during the Summer Sale and paid less than a dollar for it. Totally worth it.It is short. The puzzles are not that difficult and I finised the entire game in an hour and half.Overall, if you can get the game while it is on sale, go for it! It is not long but it is fun and beautiful to look at. I will probably play this game again when I just need a stress reliever.

Posted: July 17, 2015
												I can't complain since I bought this for 19 cents.  That's basically me selling two steam trading cards.The feeling the game gives off... I don't how many of you remember "The Very Hungry Caterpillar," but it invokes that same kind of nostalgic blast of color, something that mesmerizes you.  It is more than ten times as bright and vivid as that book, but as adults that's what it takes to overload your senses.  At the same time there is an ever-present sensation of faded-ness.  Like the bright colors are constantly waning and all your efforts is only leading you to the end of both the game and your buggy life.The game play is nothing special.  It is just a point and click with a few puzzles.Note:  Screw the beetle lock!  That took me half an hour.  That's 25% of the time spent on this game wasted on a bland rock with five bugs on it!

Posted: September 2, 2016
												full disclosure - i don't play hidden object games, and didn't realise this was one when i decided to play it next. i thought it was a puzzle game. i was wrong.i won't criticise it for it's hidden object content (though i do not understand the appeal at all) as it's unfair to mark down a game for being the genre it is. however, the other aspects are incredibly frustrating. the character model moves so slowly, which feels like unnecessary padding. pathing is terrible. there's no indication of where you can and can't go, so you have to wait an eternity for the character model to walk to a point only to find you can't go that way. the game doesn't explain any of the mechanics or puzzles - not an issue for the most part, but in 2 instances i had no idea what i had to do to move the game along and had to look at a guide to simply progress the game (oh, that mechanic that i discovered by accident that did nothing now does something in select spots on one single level? ugh). that's not clever game design.the puzzles were fairly bland - nothing that hasn't been done a million times before. but i have to mention the last one in the game...if you're colour blind, like i am - GOOD BLOODY LUCK. it was nearly impossible for me to distinguish some of the colours. terrible puzzle design.the music is nice enough, but loops too soon.visually - A+. absolutely beautiful to look at. just wish the graphics were married to a better game.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												Morphopolis is an atmospheric game where you partially control an insect in an environment, collecting specific items by clicking on them, somewhat reminiscient of those old I Spy games. I certainly had a bit of a nostalgia hard-on while playing this game, full disclaimer on that one.I'd certainly say Morphopolis is quite therapeutic (unless you hate bugs), it has calming music, a vibrant environment that somehow feels huge, empty, and filled to the brim at the same time through its artistic use of the whole bug-world. There are plenty of times where you'll feel like the game is moving way too slow, and you will be stumped heavily on a puzzle or two here and there, perhaps to a point of rage, but in the end it makes you feel more accomplished. There even is a noticable progression between levels which gives you an air on familiarity in a new, strange environment.In the end, the game doesn't take too long to beat. But the apprehension and depiction of the whole game makes it feel longer, it gives you a feeling of being accomplished and completed. It's not a wonderful, 10/10 game, but for someone who's willing to take the time and mild frustration to complete the game, it can be a nice gaming/art experience.Is ok.

Posted: October 16, 2015
												I have very mixed feelings about this game. On the one hand, it's very pretty, and the puzzles and scavenger hunts are mostly fun and clever, which is usually all I ask for in a game like this. The setting is gorgeously done and sucks you in right away. When I first started playing, I was thrilled with this game; my only complaint for the first three levels would have been that the puzzles were too easy, and that's highly forgivable in a game meant to attract players of all ranges in age and skill. On the other, the inability to either back out of a puzzle once it was initiated (short of forcing the game to minimize/quit) or save midlevel meant every new puzzle involved a level of commitment and occasional stress I really wasn't looking for in a casual point-and-click. Since the only two puzzles I had real trouble with were at the end of their levels, I had to redo those entire levels just to get at the puzzles again, which was kind of aggravating since this is the kind of game that's only fun when you don't already know the answers.Despite the extreme minimalism in terms of storytelling, I was also intrigued by the narrative, and disappointed when there was no real closure to the story. The last level ended about like any other. Did my weird glowy bug spirit make it to where they were going? What was the ultimate point of this strange and arduous journey? I'm not saying I want concrete answers, but some kind of closure would have been nice. It's similar to the problem I had with Lilly Looking Through, which played like the demo to a game I'd love to play in full.I wish Steam reviews didn't require you to say whether you recommend or don't recommend a game, because there's enough good in here that I'd like to recommend it but enough bad that I'd have heavy caveats. I picked Morphopolis up for ten cents during a Steam sale. For ten cents, if you like puzzles and scavenger hunts, it's pretty good. For the current price, I'm going to not recommend it. Maybe keep an eye on the folks who made Morphopolis to see what they do next, instead of getting too excited about Morphopolis itself.

Posted: October 24, 2015
												Positives:-The music is very relaxing.-The art is pretty.-Some of the puzzles are pretty fun, and you feel pretty smart for having solved them.-Nice if you like "find the hidden object"-type games.Negatives:-The controls for moving are crap.  Half the time you won't even realize you can go somewhere until you accidentally hold the mouse in the wrong area.  Other times, your bug keeps moving back and forth in the same spot as you try to find the place that'll make it go not just right, but right and downwards.  Sometimes you'll try clicking an object and end up moving your bug back over to the other screen for no apparent reason, even though you weren't clicking in that direction.-On a similar note, you are SLOW.  Slow, slow, slow, slow, SLOW.  Which wouldn't be SO bad, but since you're constantly moving back and forth between screens (using the same crummy controls) to find stuff you missed, it's just unbearable.  I feel like the game would have been at least a half an hour shorter if I could change screens faster.-So much random clicking to figure out what's important.  See, you don't actually find out what you need to collect until you click on something, like another bug, or a plant.  Sorta like they're giving you a quest.  Usually it's easy enough to figure out what needs clicking, but other times, you have no freaking idea how you're supposed to progress without taking a hint.-By level three, you'll start to recognize that the weird orange orbs are gonna need collecting before you can burrow into your next target's brain.  But no, you can't grab anything you know you're gonna need until after the 'quest' is given to you, forcing you to slowly, SLOWLY backtrack through all of the screens to grab them.  I don't mean to sound impatient, but God.  Crawl across the screen a little faster, bug.  Come on!  Hustle, hustle!-No idea where the "pathways" to the next screen are.  Have fun crawling (SLOWLY) across the screen, only to realize it's a dead end.  Then crawl (SLOWLY) back, not sure whether there's another screen, or if you're just bad at finding items.-Did I mention that you're slow?  Because you're slow.  SO FREAKING SLOW.-A couple puzzles are really annoying for the wrong reasons.  For example, the flower puzzle gives you no indication of the controls.  I spent ages clicking around and hoping something would happen, but nope!  It's actually a Chinese Checkers-style puzzle where you have to try and get all but one of the seed thingies to disappear, but without a walkthrough, I never would have figured out the rules and controls.  Figuring out what the freaking puzzle is isn't a puzzle.-No mid-level saves.  Levels aren't usually that long, but if you get stuck on something and call it quits for the night, have fun slowly, slowly, SLOWLY crawling across the screen several more times to complete the initial collection quests again.  SLOWLY.-I don't know if I just accidentally skipped it, or what (in which case it shouldn't be so easy to accidentally skip, because I'm not gonna freaking replay that last puzzle just to see it) but I went into the place I was supposed to go, and... That was it.  The game just ended.  I got an achievement, and then I was back at the menu.  Ghosts 'n' Goblins had a better ending than that!Summary:If you can get it on sale and really, REALLY like hidden object games, it might be worth it, but there are plenty of free games on the internet that aren't so, well, SLOW.  Seriously, I'm not kidding, it's really gonna get on your nerves.  Don't even think about paying the full five dollars for this.  I mean, I appreciate the effort the developers put into it, and everything, but this isn't worth two dollars and fifty cents per hour.

Posted: March 8, 2016
												Morphopolis is a very interesting, and unique game that takes place in the world of insects. There are very few games of this variety. At first glance you might think that this is just an artificial life simulator type of game (Examples of such games are Simlife, Simant, and Spore). But, you would be wrong. Because this is actually a 2D, point and click game with puzzles (LOTS of them to say the least). You start the game off by playing as a caterpillar, and you must help the caterpillar create a cocoon in order to proceed to the next level. Don't start thinking that you'll play as a caterpillar in every level, there actually are other insects in this game you can play as later on. Don't worry, I won't give away the names of the other insects or describe their appearances (assuming you're a gamer who likes surprises). There are puzzles in every level of Morphopolis. A puzzle can be accessed by collecting a certain amount of items (Sticks, berries, pollen, etc.). Some puzzles are easily solved in a matter of minutes, while others will have you leaning your head against your hand wondering how on earth you can find a solution to the current puzzle. The artwork in this game is absolutely beautiful. But the animation is somewhat cheap (Seems like the kind of animation you'd see in a Newgrounds game). Now as for the soundtrack, it's very atmospheric, and fits the game like a glove. The only complaint I have with this game is that it's too short! I managed to complete this game in a single day (I'm not kidding). Partly because the puzzles in this game are very similar to puzzles I've seen in other games. Now if you're a casual gamer, then chances are you're probably going to be playing this game much longer then I would. Overall, Morphopolis is a very well designed game that I wish could have a sequel or an expansion pack. If you like Professor Layton or any other puzzle game in general, give this one a try.

Posted: September 24, 2015
												Morphopolis knows what it wants to do.  Provide a game that runs off the player's curiosity, and provide a few simple puzzles for the player to figure out on their own.  I love how it had no dialogue, leaving me to try and figure out what the heck I was doing for most of the time.  Though it's controls are restricted to the mouse, the game still feels like the antithesis of a lot of modern games, and feels like it pays tribute to an era lost in gaming where hand holding wasn't mandatory.ProsVery pleasing asthetic.  From what I understand, it was hand-drawn, and looked very good.  A lot of life from a soft palette, and I didn't feel like any problematic circumstances were due to the visuals.Again, I had a lot of freedom (even though the gameplay was technically on rails) to explore and tackle the puzzles as they came.  You don't see that often nowadays.ConsThe music was a bit of a wash.  My experience only lasted about an hour and a half, but most of the music is just some percussion and a xylophone - which wasn't as immersive when it hasn't noticibly changed 80% through the game.  I think there were other types of music at the start of the levels, but they inevitably sounded the same.My VerdictI think anyone who is considering buying this should understand what it was made for - a brief session of immersive puzzle solving in a visualy pleasing art style.  I personally, enjoyed my experience with it (where others clearly have not).  It's short, sweet, and - though I don't think of it as a particularly memorable experience - believe it was worth my time.7 / 10

The armony of the colours, the balance of the music and the speed with which you move takes you to a state of peace. Posted: June 18, 2016
												This is a slow paced find-it. Not everyone will like it, especially if you don't know what you're getting into before you start. It's more of a relaxing game to wind down to. It's obvious that it is a port, though. The music is both calming yet unsettling at times. The hint button doesn't work but I didn't need it. The controls can be really slow. It's more about the visual experience than anything and you shouldn't be in a hurry playing this. Reminds me vaguely of "The Plan". You go from being what feels like an almost helpless bug to what ends up feeling more intimidating. I got this in a bundle with two other games and this is, by far, the best one. I just wish it was longer.

Posted: June 18, 2016
												Well....you get what you pay for. I think I paid $0.60. The art is amazing but like what others said, that's it. Puzzles are easy until you get to the end...hold your thought on that one, I'll come back to it.You can't save during a level, or at least I couldn't find how. Controls are iffy sometimes. The bug will do a little dance when it doesn't know what you want it to do (I don't think that's intentional). No ending. Music is decent. Now on to the last puzzle. Insanely difficult. I had to cheat. It was so hard that it didn't fit the scale of difficulty for the previous levels and puzzles. Most of the gameplay is find the hidden what ever then finish a simple puzzle. The last slider puzzle non-sense just doesn't work for the game. Really aggravating and once you look for a solution online it takes away your sense of achievement. I do admit I had some fun with it but not enough to recommend it. And that last puzzle leaves me sore, like I got stung by one of those trippy bees.

Posted: June 25, 2016
												Some facts and a few downsides you should know:Playtime is about 1,5 to 2 hours.About 15 - 20% seem to complete the game.Controls are clunky and thus movement could be better.Sometimes you end up just clicking everywhere because objectives aren't made clear. This distracts from the beauty of the game.The riddles themselves are also kind of standard, suffer from glitchy controls as well though. Movement is very, very slow. Combined with the control issues this might be a show stopper for some people. If you don't have the patience you should better avoid this.I assume most of the problems originate from the game being made to work for mobile.That said:The game is beautiful. It's not long, it's not complex, but the artwork itself is really well done and cute. If you're pulled in by the screenshots you might as well enjoy it.The music is very nice as well.I'd say the difficulty of the puzzles is satisfying. Not too hard, not too easy either.It's more of an art game than a real game. If you enjoy it that way you will not be disappointed.The pricing is very fair for the content length.

Posted: January 6, 2016
												One of the most beautiful games I have played. The layout itself it's a great piece of art. The armony of the colours, the balance of the music and the speed with which you move takes you to a state of peace. As for the game itself, you play as a bug trying to collect flowers, mushrooms or other insects as required. For every collection you complete, you must solve a puzzle, mostly graphic ones. You have to finish each of the 5 levels in one playthrough, since you can't save your progress, but that's quite fine since they don't take so long. You can complete the game in 1 or 2 hours the most, but it's totally worth the price. The cons of the game would maybe be the annoying beep when you ask for a tip and that you can't exit the game normally but you have to crash it instead.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												I felt compelled to check out this game when it was on sale for $.19, because how could such a beautiful looking puzzler be only $.19? I'm so glad I did. This is a very small, quirky game, but it's a beautiful little gem well worth your time.The music and hand-drawn insect and nature art create a very peaceful, otherworldly atmosphere to explore. There are no words or text instructions, but the game has a hint button which will highlight your next step if you can't figure out what to do next. Gameplay is basically hidden item-gathering exploration, interspersed with a puzzle in each chapter. The game progresses in a way that feels natural to understand. The puzzles can be tricky, but not impossible, and everything about the game is satisfying when you figure things out on your own. That said, if you get totally stuck on a puzzle and need a nudge in the right direction, check out the excellent Steam guides people have written.Some caveats: There are five chapters, and if you close the game in the middle of a chapter, you'll have to start from the beginning of that chapter again. I can't find this as a flaw since the chapters take so little time to complete (you can finish the game with all achievements in 2-3 hours), but it's something to know before you play.You also can't close the game during a puzzle, but again, most of them don't take very long to solve. One reviewer complained that puzzles have no reset button if you mess them up, but none of them can be messed up except the chapter 4 puzzle, which does have a reset button (the yellow spot on the right of the puzzle).This is a very small, lovely little world to spend a couple of hours in, and I recommend it.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												Beautiful graphics.  Takes about 3 hours to guide your 'insect' through 5 stages.  You have to collect things blended into the background and solve several puzzles.  The game saves after each stage but there is no manual save.  In most cases I dislike that but in this case it would have been excessive.  You just have to relax and imagine you're exploring a new world and take it as it comes.  If you're completely stuck, there is help to find the hidden items but the puzzles just have to be solved.  Great deal for the quality!

Posted: July 16, 2016
												Not exactly sure what just happened but it wasn’t bad.Story:You’re a bug that needs to give eggs to a different bug and then in the next level you play it? I’m not sure if I understood that correctly but overall, no story.Gameplay:It’s a point and click where the objective is to collect things. You get quests by clicking on insects which tell you to collect things which open paths (sometimes) to other insects and collectibles. It’s a simple process really. The fetch quests aren’t too bad as the entire game is about exploration. At the end, you just move on to a different level. Each level has about 4 rooms and you backtrack a lot which isn’t too much of a problem as they are small but your speed is low. Controlling the movement of the bug seems really not that accurate but you usually just use it to move to a different screen. Sometimes there are mini puzzles that show up like connecting ropes, matching colors, or a literal puzzle. They aren’t too annoying but just seem like time lengthens (except the last one can go ♥♥♥♥ itself).Overall, the gameplay is simple and not that bad. Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)The game looks fantastic and maintains a solid 60. Everything seems handdrawn and the sheer detail is just amazing. However, there are black bars around the top and bottom which are annoying. There isn’t a setting menu for resolution, controls (although a mouse is all you need), or music which is annoying. The music itself is really nice and nature-y (?) while having a sense of foreboding. Final Thoughts:I liked it. It was different and interesting. Overall, worth a look although wait for a sale.

Posted: March 8, 2016
												Morphopolis is a very interesting, and unique game that takes place in the world of insects. There are very few games of this variety. At first glance you might think that this is just an artificial life simulator type of game (Examples of such games are Simlife, Simant, and Spore). But, you would be wrong. Because this is actually a 2D, point and click game with puzzles (LOTS of them to say the least). You start the game off by playing as a caterpillar, and you must help the caterpillar create a cocoon in order to proceed to the next level. Don't start thinking that you'll play as a caterpillar in every level, there actually are other insects in this game you can play as later on. Don't worry, I won't give away the names of the other insects or describe their appearances (assuming you're a gamer who likes surprises). There are puzzles in every level of Morphopolis. A puzzle can be accessed by collecting a certain amount of items (Sticks, berries, pollen, etc.). Some puzzles are easily solved in a matter of minutes, while others will have you leaning your head against your hand wondering how on earth you can find a solution to the current puzzle. The artwork in this game is absolutely beautiful. But the animation is somewhat cheap (Seems like the kind of animation you'd see in a Newgrounds game). Now as for the soundtrack, it's very atmospheric, and fits the game like a glove. The only complaint I have with this game is that it's too short! I managed to complete this game in a single day (I'm not kidding). Partly because the puzzles in this game are very similar to puzzles I've seen in other games. Now if you're a casual gamer, then chances are you're probably going to be playing this game much longer then I would. Overall, Morphopolis is a very well designed game that I wish could have a sequel or an expansion pack. If you like Professor Layton or any other puzzle game in general, give this one a try.

Posted: November 11, 2015
												This is a cute game where you control various bugs which go around solving puzzles and collecting hidden objects. It looks vaguely like one of those adult colouring in books and has a calming (if somewhat repetitive) Zen-ish soundtrack to go along with it.The main problem is that the puzzles vary wildly in their difficulty. Some are really easy, like the Memory puzzle with beetles with different numbers of spots on their back or the glowworm pattern repeating puzzle. Others are harder and really difficult to do without a walkthrough, like the petal Draughts and the last Beetle Lock (never doing that again). There are also a few weird bugs (!!) here and there, like when my aphid (part 3 I think?) refused to dissolve the little red balls surrounding the squiggles I had to collect (I prefer to call them squiggles to imagining they're gross maggots or whatever). Like, he would spray his green goop and make his little sucking motion, but he just wouldn't suck up the red balls. Resetting the game entirely and redoing everything he did it fine, but that was really weird and I suspect would have put off someone who does not like wasting their time as much as I do.It would also be really nice to include colourblind options in this game. A lot of the puzzles really need it (like the beetle lock puzzle) and, besides, it's the year of our luigi 2015 - you should be including colourblind options just by default.I would tentatively recommend this game, because it's cheap and very pretty. I wouldn't recommend paying more than a dollar or two for it, though.

Posted: March 8, 2016
												Morphopolis is a very interesting, and unique game that takes place in the world of insects. There are very few games of this variety. At first glance you might think that this is just an artificial life simulator type of game (Examples of such games are Simlife, Simant, and Spore). But, you would be wrong. Because this is actually a 2D, point and click game with puzzles (LOTS of them to say the least). You start the game off by playing as a caterpillar, and you must help the caterpillar create a cocoon in order to proceed to the next level. Don't start thinking that you'll play as a caterpillar in every level, there actually are other insects in this game you can play as later on. Don't worry, I won't give away the names of the other insects or describe their appearances (assuming you're a gamer who likes surprises). There are puzzles in every level of Morphopolis. A puzzle can be accessed by collecting a certain amount of items (Sticks, berries, pollen, etc.). Some puzzles are easily solved in a matter of minutes, while others will have you leaning your head against your hand wondering how on earth you can find a solution to the current puzzle. The artwork in this game is absolutely beautiful. But the animation is somewhat cheap (Seems like the kind of animation you'd see in a Newgrounds game). Now as for the soundtrack, it's very atmospheric, and fits the game like a glove. The only complaint I have with this game is that it's too short! I managed to complete this game in a single day (I'm not kidding). Partly because the puzzles in this game are very similar to puzzles I've seen in other games. Now if you're a casual gamer, then chances are you're probably going to be playing this game much longer then I would. Overall, Morphopolis is a very well designed game that I wish could have a sequel or an expansion pack. If you like Professor Layton or any other puzzle game in general, give this one a try.

Posted: July 16, 2016
												Not exactly sure what just happened but it wasn’t bad.Story:You’re a bug that needs to give eggs to a different bug and then in the next level you play it? I’m not sure if I understood that correctly but overall, no story.Gameplay:It’s a point and click where the objective is to collect things. You get quests by clicking on insects which tell you to collect things which open paths (sometimes) to other insects and collectibles. It’s a simple process really. The fetch quests aren’t too bad as the entire game is about exploration. At the end, you just move on to a different level. Each level has about 4 rooms and you backtrack a lot which isn’t too much of a problem as they are small but your speed is low. Controlling the movement of the bug seems really not that accurate but you usually just use it to move to a different screen. Sometimes there are mini puzzles that show up like connecting ropes, matching colors, or a literal puzzle. They aren’t too annoying but just seem like time lengthens (except the last one can go ♥♥♥♥ itself).Overall, the gameplay is simple and not that bad. Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)The game looks fantastic and maintains a solid 60. Everything seems handdrawn and the sheer detail is just amazing. However, there are black bars around the top and bottom which are annoying. There isn’t a setting menu for resolution, controls (although a mouse is all you need), or music which is annoying. The music itself is really nice and nature-y (?) while having a sense of foreboding. Final Thoughts:I liked it. It was different and interesting. Overall, worth a look although wait for a sale.

												full disclosure - i don't play hidden object games, and didn't realise this was one when i decided to play it next. i thought it was a puzzle game. i was wrong.i won't criticise it for it's hidden object content (though i do not understand the appeal at all) as it's unfair to mark down a game for being the genre it is. however, the other aspects are incredibly frustrating. the character model moves so slowly, which feels like unnecessary padding. pathing is terrible. there's no indication of where you can and can't go, so you have to wait an eternity for the character model to walk to a point only to find you can't go that way. the game doesn't explain any of the mechanics or puzzles - not an issue for the most part, but in 2 instances i had no idea what i had to do to move the game along and had to look at a guide to simply progress the game (oh, that mechanic that i discovered by accident that did nothing now does something in select spots on one single level? ugh). that's not clever game design.the puzzles were fairly bland - nothing that hasn't been done a million times before. but i have to mention the last one in the game...if you're colour blind, like i am - GOOD BLOODY LUCK. it was nearly impossible for me to distinguish some of the colours. terrible puzzle design.the music is nice enough, but loops too soon.visually - A+. absolutely beautiful to look at. just wish the graphics were married to a better game.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												I felt compelled to check out this game when it was on sale for $.19, because how could such a beautiful looking puzzler be only $.19? I'm so glad I did. This is a very small, quirky game, but it's a beautiful little gem well worth your time.The music and hand-drawn insect and nature art create a very peaceful, otherworldly atmosphere to explore. There are no words or text instructions, but the game has a hint button which will highlight your next step if you can't figure out what to do next. Gameplay is basically hidden item-gathering exploration, interspersed with a puzzle in each chapter. The game progresses in a way that feels natural to understand. The puzzles can be tricky, but not impossible, and everything about the game is satisfying when you figure things out on your own. That said, if you get totally stuck on a puzzle and need a nudge in the right direction, check out the excellent Steam guides people have written.Some caveats: There are five chapters, and if you close the game in the middle of a chapter, you'll have to start from the beginning of that chapter again. I can't find this as a flaw since the chapters take so little time to complete (you can finish the game with all achievements in 2-3 hours), but it's something to know before you play.You also can't close the game during a puzzle, but again, most of them don't take very long to solve. One reviewer complained that puzzles have no reset button if you mess them up, but none of them can be messed up except the chapter 4 puzzle, which does have a reset button (the yellow spot on the right of the puzzle).This is a very small, lovely little world to spend a couple of hours in, and I recommend it.

												A very laid back gaming experience, you go through a point&click adventure beginning as a small catapillar and then morphing into larger insects as you go throughout the game. You will find yourself looking for objects in a certain amount, and when you reach that amount of objects it takes you to a small puzzle. Complete the puzzles and move further in the game by going inside the insect you're helping.The Puzzles are very simple if you take the time to think things through, and the only downfall of the game is the walking animation takes FOREVER. Seriously, these insects walk slow, and it will make you become very impatient. (If you're like me).I recommend using the walking animation time to check out the amazing art done for the game, the backgrounds are really beautiful with lots of color and imagination, the game itself is of beautiful design. Achievements are very easy to come by, I know I felt very refreshed when getting all the achievements in one go. You will not regret playing!

												First off, know that this is an "art game". It is extremely laid-back and casual, and there is no rush or time limits. The character movements are a bit buggy (pun intented) and jerky at times, which really takes away from the game as a whole. Play this game if you enjoy artsy games like Flow and Flower, or even the 1st level of Spore. It feels a bit like you're looking at a beautiful painting and imagining all the movements in your mind, but they ARE actually happening. Speaking of the graphics, they are very well done, with close up and background objects blurry, and the midground in-focus. This game left me wanting more, as the ending was a bit abrupt. Totally room for expansion if the developers wanted to pursue that, but who knows if that will happen.

Posted: September 14, 2015
												Morphopolis is a very short game, but I really enjoyed it. For the first few moments, I was frustrated, but then you have that "aha" satisfaction for figuring out the mechanisms without being told. Yes, there is a lot of moving back and forth. But the soundtrack is lovely, the visuals are delightful, and it was a very relaxing experience. I do wish there were more levels, though. I finished the game too quickly to even get one card drop (which isn't a big deal for me but gives a sense of how short it is). Definitely consider it if you like puzzle games and it's on sale.

Posted: September 1, 2015
												Although some may commend it for its beautiful art style; the gameplay is infuriating, unrewarding, and far too slow for me to really appreciate all Morphopolis has to offer. There also isn't a menu where I can tinker with the sounds, which means I have to listen to that annoying bug chirp in the background for the entirety of the game.The controls are maddening. You click and drag your cursor in the direction that you want the bug to move, but unfortunately the controls don't always work. You'll find yourself dragging, only to watch your bug go back and forth. In certain points, you'll have to wait for an animation to finish until you can move your bug again - which can be upsetting if the controls are screwing up constantly. There is also tons of backtracking, which makes every level feel tedious. Since every level that you play seems to end with you collecting a serious of orange balls, I know that I am going to have to do that at the end, but I can't collect them all before I receive the quest. Subsequently, I'm forced to backtrack through every single level to collect all of the orange balls in order to go to the next level that will ask me to do the same thing.Backtracking wouldn't be that much of an issue if your character didn't trek along at the speed of molasses. The two hours that you'll spend completing this game could be cut down to about an hour and half if the bug would move just a tad bit quicker. Unfortunately, that never happens and you're forced to watch your bug move uncomfortably slow through every area - which can be upsetting if you're someone that enjoys gameplay that actually moves at an appropriate pace.Also, the last puzzle is a treat. By that, I mean, you'll be shouting at your computer screen and wondering why the hell anyone would develop a puzzle as ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as the one you're playing. In the end, Morphopolis is slow, boring, and unrewarding - the gameplay is too little movement, too much grinding and that's just no fun. I cannot recommend this game.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												This game is actually really interesting. It’s a beautiful piece of art with high details and bright colors. No, I am not talking about a painting; I’m talking about the game although the game is like a painting in a way. It has a very calming feel that helps you relax as you try to work out the puzzles and find the items in which you’re looking for. It’s a very short game, only about an hour or two depending on how good you are at puzzles and hidden object games. Behind the puzzles and artwork, we have an interesting sort of story that is abstract enough for you to take what you want from it. It is one of those games that might have a deeper meaning if you really want to look for it.They don’t really explain a story line for the game much, you are thrust straight into the game as a little larva or caterpillar wiggling around. It keeps you in that insect world as you go from a small larva to a grasshopper to a bee and so on. There aren’t any times that you actually fly or jump which is kind of strange but you walk around gathering items and the end of the stage is crawling into what looks like a carcass of the bug you will be next. I know the game is called morphopolis and is supposed to be about metamorphosis but this feels more like you taking over the dead bug instead. The game play is… at times its pretty good when you get into the puzzles but the movement of the character walking around is a little hard to deal with. Times when I am clicking to find the objects, the little character that I was playing would move and go into a different scene when I am not ready for it. That’s the problem with clicking the screen being both for finding items and moving your character. There are times when my character also had trouble finding the pathways I wanted him to go on.  I think it would have been a bit easier if they had the arrow keys to move the character as I could hit the down button or up to go on those paths. The character moves very slowly which can make that part of the game boring when you have to go back and forward to collect items. There is a lot of back tracking in this and it would have been nice to be able to have the character speed up. There is one other problem that I do have with the puzzles. The puzzles don’t tell you how to do them, you sort of just have to try different things to figure it out. There was one puzzle I got stuck on because nothing I did was actually working that I had to look up what the puzzle was supposed to be so I could play it.The artwork is so amazing. It’s very high detail and is almost like a surreal painting with how playful the colors and designs are. The problem with this though is that there are times you can’t find the path you need to go on most of the time. The paths just blend in with the background or are really hard to figure out. They luckily have it so that when you click your character, a couple green sparkles will resonate from him and travel a little way along the path though sometimes its hard to see depending on how high detailed the area is around them. On the other hand, the high detail does make finding the objects your looking for all the more rewarding as it is hard to see them. The music is so calming and a little mysterious. There is one track through the whole thing and yet I never got bored of it. It’s a piano solo that almost put me to sleep a couple of times during the long walk parts. That is all I can really say on it as its just calming.Overall, it was a nice little game to play. Is it worth the money that it is on steam right now? Maybe not. I got the game on a steam sale and It was worth the amount I paid for but I’m not sure if it’s the full $4.99 worth. My recommendation is to get it on sale because it is a good game, and it is beautiful. If you get it for the normal price, then you’re mostly paying for the artwork.

Posted: September 6, 2015
												The game "Morphopolis" is a pretty little, short puzzle/hidden objects game that builds on a relaxing atmosphere in a natural, colourful environment (to be more exact: the world of insects).In five levels you take control of an insect trying to get to the end of the level but a row of obstacles get in your way. To get rid of them you need to solve a few puzzles or find a certain amount of objects (which is more challenging than it sounds considering the detailed backgrounds you have to look at to find the objects).What's nice is that the game is quite relaxing which is because of the soothing easy-listening soundtrack and the design which make you feel you're in some sort of jungle right now.You won't get any help in the game on what a puzzle is about but most of the time it's easy to find out. Only the very last puzzle in level 5 is very tricky.Aside from the lack of game help in the game, it can get very annoying when the screen moves and you have to way until the next screen slowly appears (because your insect moves slowly, too).So if you like a short puzzle/hidden objects game for about 1-2 hours and if you don't dislike insects, feel free to entertain yourself. But because it's so short, better keep your eyes open for a discount offer instead of paying full 4,99 € for this game.

Posted: April 12, 2016
												Morphopolis is a very artsy game.  Beautiful and colorful and a little surreal.At it's core it's a hidden object puzzle game where you find objects and then use them on other objects. Sometimes this initiates a puzzle that you have to complete.  Some objects in the environment you need to click on to initiate the ability to go on an object hunt which was a little annoying, though not unfair. Just remember if it looks important click on it once to see if it pops up that it wants something.The game barely has any instructions and mostly you're just on your own.  But despite the lack of any prompts that tell you what to do the game doesn't just leave you hanging as the puzzles do make enough sense that one should be able to piece together what you need to do. I only have problems with one puzzle that I needed to look up how to do it.Morphopolis feels like it was designed to play on a tablet, phone, or any sort of touch screen as the controls are 'click & hold' or 'click & drag' oriented. Though this did not really subtract from the game for me.The game is short (I beat it in about 2 hours) and does not really have any replay value but I still say buy it if you got a couple of extra dollars available. It's a nice little game to waste some time on and it's dang pretty to look at.P.S. You'll 100% the game on your first play-though probably.

Posted: July 16, 2016
												Not exactly sure what just happened but it wasn’t bad.Story:You’re a bug that needs to give eggs to a different bug and then in the next level you play it? I’m not sure if I understood that correctly but overall, no story.Gameplay:It’s a point and click where the objective is to collect things. You get quests by clicking on insects which tell you to collect things which open paths (sometimes) to other insects and collectibles. It’s a simple process really. The fetch quests aren’t too bad as the entire game is about exploration. At the end, you just move on to a different level. Each level has about 4 rooms and you backtrack a lot which isn’t too much of a problem as they are small but your speed is low. Controlling the movement of the bug seems really not that accurate but you usually just use it to move to a different screen. Sometimes there are mini puzzles that show up like connecting ropes, matching colors, or a literal puzzle. They aren’t too annoying but just seem like time lengthens (except the last one can go ♥♥♥♥ itself).Overall, the gameplay is simple and not that bad. Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)The game looks fantastic and maintains a solid 60. Everything seems handdrawn and the sheer detail is just amazing. However, there are black bars around the top and bottom which are annoying. There isn’t a setting menu for resolution, controls (although a mouse is all you need), or music which is annoying. The music itself is really nice and nature-y (?) while having a sense of foreboding. Final Thoughts:I liked it. It was different and interesting. Overall, worth a look although wait for a sale.

Posted: July 30, 2016
												I really wasn't expecting this game to be very good when I picked it up dirt-cheap on sale. The art style looked weird (in a good way) and the idea of playing as a bug (who crawls so bloody sloooow I might add) seemed a bit strange too. However, I'd just joined Steam properly (I made my account 6 years ago and never used it) and needed a few games to get me started. I was pleasantly surprised by this game. It wasn't long at all. Five chapters/levels in total, each lasting around 15-30 minutes each, depending on your puzzle skills.   The game plays like a triple-mix of platformer/hidden-object/puzzle game, with the end-goal in each chapter being to evolve your bug to the next stage in it's life.  The puzzles are fairly simple, but some can become a bit tricky as there is no guide or text to tell you what you should be doing to solve each one. I would recommend this game to others,  as I had fun while it lasted, and the level design is very nice on the eye. Great work.

												Play as an insect, find objects hidden in the lovely artwork to give to other insects so you can find more objects. Broken up with some fairly traditional puzzles. Gameplay is slow, simple and repetitive, which  is good if you just want to relax and enjoy the art, less so if you're looking for constant stimulation.UI is minimilistic, with no text and only the vaguest of instruction. Some of the objects and puzzles can be a little hard to find or complete. There is a timer based hint system for the objects, but no such luck for the puzzles.Should take an hour and a half to two hours to complete as long as you don't get completely stuck on any of the puzzles and/or you're colourblind.

Posted: January 6, 2016
												One of the most beautiful games I have played. The layout itself it's a great piece of art. The armony of the colours, the balance of the music and the speed with which you move takes you to a state of peace. As for the game itself, you play as a bug trying to collect flowers, mushrooms or other insects as required. For every collection you complete, you must solve a puzzle, mostly graphic ones. You have to finish each of the 5 levels in one playthrough, since you can't save your progress, but that's quite fine since they don't take so long. You can complete the game in 1 or 2 hours the most, but it's totally worth the price. The cons of the game would maybe be the annoying beep when you ask for a tip and that you can't exit the game normally but you have to crash it instead.

Posted: April 15, 2015
												The atmospheric soundtrack and the very beautiful visual environment art attracted my interest and kept me playing the game from the beginning till the end.The game lasts around 3 hours (maybe much less if you are used to solving puzzles) and its divided in 5 levels/stages in which there are 8 puzzles in total. Some of them are easy and some needs time and good attention/focus to solve them. The last one is more challenging, something like a soft version of Rubik's cube (but with insects)!At the gameplay you take the role of an insect that evolves/transforms after each level/stage of the game. Its a point and click game, you don't use keyboard, and you collect various of objects to feed them to some other insects that are blocking your way forward and during this you will encounter to solve these 8 puzzles that I mention before.TL;DR: Its a nice point and click adventure and puzzle game with very beautiful art and atmospheric soundtrack. It lasts around 2-3 hours and it has 5 levels and 8 puzzles in total. If it worths the full price... idk, it depends on the person. I bought it -95% only to farm the cards but I really liked the game and I played it till the end!Cons: Its really short game. It could have had more levels and puzzles.9/10

Posted: December 29, 2015
												Morphopolis is an atmospheric game where you partially control an insect in an environment, collecting specific items by clicking on them, somewhat reminiscient of those old I Spy games. I certainly had a bit of a nostalgia hard-on while playing this game, full disclaimer on that one.I'd certainly say Morphopolis is quite therapeutic (unless you hate bugs), it has calming music, a vibrant environment that somehow feels huge, empty, and filled to the brim at the same time through its artistic use of the whole bug-world. There are plenty of times where you'll feel like the game is moving way too slow, and you will be stumped heavily on a puzzle or two here and there, perhaps to a point of rage, but in the end it makes you feel more accomplished. There even is a noticable progression between levels which gives you an air on familiarity in a new, strange environment.In the end, the game doesn't take too long to beat. But the apprehension and depiction of the whole game makes it feel longer, it gives you a feeling of being accomplished and completed. It's not a wonderful, 10/10 game, but for someone who's willing to take the time and mild frustration to complete the game, it can be a nice gaming/art experience.Is ok.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												While the game art is indeed really beautiful, I sadly can't say the same thing for the gameplay.Character movement is painfully slow. I understand that it's supposed to be a relaxing game, but come on.The "hold-click this part of the screen to make your bug move to a general direction of where you're clicking at" PnC system is really awkward to do, causing the bug to sometimes end up dancing back and forth, confused of where it should go.The roots/pipes puzzle made almost no sense, while the other puzzles on the other hand are pretty okay. The flower draughts could use a bit of an in-game hint because NOT EVERYONE HAS PLAYED DRAUGHTS BEFORE.Some hidden objects are "too well-hidden", rendering looking for one without a hint is almost impossible. But that was probably just me.The "story" itself. What is this game about? An insect version of the body snatcher?Still, despite all the gripes on the gameplay, it was indeed an eye-pleasing experience. I'm glad it was also very cheap.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												This game is odd, but in a good way.I can't tell what it's trying to be; whether it's a child's game, with dark, underlying themes, or whether it's an adventure into a mystical world just below normal human perception. But whatever it is, it's incredible. The puzzles were mostly easy (with the exception of the trickier final puzzle) and the gameplay was point and click, which searching aspects. But this, for me, was less of a game, and more of an experience. The art was absolutely awesome, and gave the world a unique and intriguing twist I haven't seen in a story game before.Should you buy it? That depends. If you're the kind of person who sits down for five minutes, leaves, and comes back, don't buy this. But if you like to take your time, and involve yourself in a game, this story without words would appeal to you like no other.The soundtrack made me just sit down and listen to the music, while the screen displayed just a menu, for about five minutes before starting the game. Each environment gave me a new sense of accomplishment, and I just look back on it and smile. That is, until I play it again.It is a short game, but it will change you.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												I'd have to describe this as "a pretty poor game". That is to say, "it's pretty", and "it's a poor game". I picked it up dirt cheap because my never-plays-computer-games girlfriend (and I) enjoyed Machinariam and The Tiny Bang Story, the advertised equivalents, but aside from the nice art style there was no comparison. She lost interest in under ten minutes, and I only persevered because I didn't want to waste my 20 cents...It's nice-looking, searching out the grubs and beetles to collect is about as entertaining as finding the goals in any other such game, and the occasional puzzles you unlock are adequate (though few), but the pointless requirement to click-and-hold on invisible paths to compel the insect to transition between screens was surely intended to draw out a game that could otherwise be finished in half the time. Naturally, you have to page back-and-forth to trigger new requests to satisfy, but making me wait doing nothing with the mouse button pressed was an annoyance. It didn't help that on my ageing PC the game often ran like a three-legged dog with terminal asthma; I finished it in 2 hours, but it could have been 30 minutes. This is five levels of hide-and-seek that offers no reward for the ultimate completion: beat the last puzzle, it just goes back to the level-selection screen and that's it. Literally no indicator that you've finished the game, other than the absence of a Number 6 to click on. Not even a pretty picture, and given that the art is this thing's only selling point that just seems lazy. It feels like something that was made by a team who watched games being played without ever playing one themselves. Nice art is not enough, not nearly.

Posted: March 16, 2016
												The gorgeous artwork and breathtaking color palette are the only reasons to play this game. I'd add the soothing music, but that gets repetitive after a while. There is next to no guidance from the game on what to do, which would be fine if gameplay were at all intuitive, which it definitely isn't. There's not even any help on using the menu system; I found out the hard way that clicking the menu icon would lose me all progress on the level, with no warning at all. The puzzles aren't very well designed, and although it's touch screen compatible, the touch screen function doesn't work that well, sometimes taking several tries to get it to respond, so I ended up just using my mouse. I'd stay away from this unless you are really into the eye candy aspect.

But I'm sure some will be proselyted by the game's visual and auditory appeal.  8/10

Posted: May 23, 2015
												This game can seem quite complex due to the lack of a tutorial (all you get is a few hand indications at the beginning and then are expected to know what to do from there). Also, just a heads up, there is no explanation on how to solve the puzzles but if you tinker around you tend to figure them out for yourself. There are 5 levels that generally stay the same difficulty but only grow with more "tasks" (i.e. collect petals, etc). You're bug form changes with each level and does get some "special abilities" with the different morphs  (i.e. buzzing your wings to blow away petals so you can recover seeds, that sort of thing)  Overall, I would say its a 7.5/10Pros:-Beautiful scenery-Nice music-Decent conceptCons:-No explanations on how to solve puzzles (but if you play a lot of Artifex Mundi games you probably stand a better chance)-Extremely short (i got a perfect game in under an hour......)Ehs:-Movement is weird-You are incredibly slow which is probably to make the game last longer -What exactly are we doing to the giant bugs at the end of the levels? O.o

Posted: May 22, 2015
												This puzzle game was such a calming and interesting break from the norm. Much like the hidden puzzle games you see on FB but with more interactivity and a hint of adventure as the character discovers and grows. The soundtrack played perfectly to each environment and made you feel like you were in the scene, which added to the desire to progress to the next screen/level.Some of the puzzles were not clear as to the steps needed to progress but as your character is a bug which doesn't know how to read, it works to have to figure it out without any assistance.Will recommend this to anyone! and will be looking for more like it.

Posted: May 8, 2015
												Artsy hidden object points&click game. The puzzles are decent and the objects are hard enough to find. There is a hint button with a fairly low cooldown that points to a missed object if there is one in the area of use, or plays a sound meaning there is no hidden object here. There is no introduction or hints to the puzzles; you'll have to figure it all out yourself.Very clunky movement/pathing. Have to hold down the mouse button to move. A lot of backtracking and the bug is really slow.The art and music are fantastically atmospheric though. Play for a meditation type entertainment rather than mentally challenging, though some of the puzzles do take some brain work.All achievements are earned on first run. The ingame menu consists of 'to title menu' and 'return to game' and the title menu of chapter select and exit game. So options are extremely limited. There is no save button, and the puzzles have no exit button, so you'll have to restart level if you have to quit. The game is short; only five small levels with 2-6 areas in each. Recommended for the artsy, atmospheric, meditational feeling it has. All the small nuisances makes it not worth its price unless on sale though.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												Amazingly Detailed game, really nice Soundtrack to match, and interesting puzzles.The Game is short,  with only 5 levels and has a slow gameplay, but you will definitely enjoy it. Posted: May 7, 2015
												3/5A Visual and Relaxing hour.Morphoplis is a point and click hidden object/puzzle game.  VERY EASY.  Don't expect much of a challange.  The game is more about experiencing the artwork and ralaxing story line.  There are no time limits and no lives. Just play and explore the art. You only need a mouse to play, and  it should take about an hour to get through all 5 levels. No story really, just play along.I wouldn't pay more than 50 cents on the game; but for that, it's worth it.

Posted: May 17, 2015
												I did like this game but I probably wouldn't play it again after finishing it. Moving each bug through the 5 levels was really painful in parts, your path is invisible and if you happen to drag or click your mouse elsewhere your bug will move into the next scene before you're ready, so you have to go back again... this happened quite a few times.Extra points for puzzles I haven't seen before in other click and points, but that very last puzzle... another painful aspect.Overall a very beautiful game, wasn't as relaxing for me since I found the haphazard movements very annoying. Wasn't worth full price for me, had I bought it on sale I might be more positive about it.

Posted: April 25, 2015
												Very pretty but it doesn't work right. I think they should check to see if the game is going to work on a desktop with Vista before they put a game up for sale. Designers might also consider putting in an auto solve button where a player can just watch the computer put the petals of the flower in place. As it is I tried the first flower puzzle and wasn't sure the game was working right. Moving the caterpillar along the branch didn't work right. I couldn't get the petals to go where I needed them so I assume there's something wrong with the flower puzzle. I have a bunch of other games with horrible, awkward controls so why would a designer think I wanted to spend a lot of time fiddling and researching how to do the simplest thing with a 25 cent game? Just put in an auto solve button and let me use that. If I want to do it myself I promise I won't use the auto solve. Either that or make sure your game works right and has some adequate text to explain how to get things done.

Posted: April 25, 2015
												This game is a wonderful blend of gorgeous art/music and excellent puzzle gameplay. It's challenging in a good way. The levels get a bit repetative, but I still found it fun. The only annoying part is that the bug character you play as moves really slowly. If it could speed up a bit then this game would be perfect. I also wish there were more levels to play, as this ends rather quickly. -if you like point & click then you will like this game-if you don't like point & click then you will still like this game because it employs the style in a way that still is fun and challenging.

												Absolutely stunning visuals & soothing music with ambient sounds. It's very short though, which is unfortunate because I could have easily played another ten levels or so of this game. Considering I got it for $0.19, it was absolutely worth what I paid & I would likely play it again because it is so relaxing. I wouldn't pay much more than a dollar for this game though.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												If you like walking around as a bug that uses the reanimated corpses of other bugs as a mean of transportation, then boy howdy do I have a game for you. However, if you don't like spending 55% of your time waiting for your slow♥♥♥♥♥bug to work its way across the screens, then this game probably isn't going to be one of your favourites. The controls are honestly horrible, but the overall gameplay isn't bad. The puzzles are solid and make you stop and think. However, I could have done without the overly minimalist "tutorial" and buttons. I don't even know why the help button is there, because it didn't ever do anything. I don't even know if it was actually a help button. Maybe it was just a question mark that you can press repeatedly to get your frustration out when you just can't figure out what to do next. Who knows. Overall I'd give this game like a 6/10.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												A simple game with beautiful artwork. Didn't take me long to figure out the controls unlike many of the reviews here. It is very short, completed everything in under two hours, with only one puzzle causing me any trouble whatsoever, where I didn't realise dragging was an option. Not worth the retail price, but I bought it for 15pence which was worth the two hours appreciating the artwork. A nice calming game, nothing more.
