Buy it for the aesthetics!The biggest plus point of the game is it's art. And the soothing soundtracks.I loved it and that was the main reason I got myself to playing it.If the aesthetics of the game don't sell it to you, Morphopolis probably isn't for you.There are total 5 chapters in the game and each chapter has 1 hidden object puzzle and 1-2 some other puzzle.Out of those, I had difficulty solving only one or two of them. The rest weren't that difficult.And completing each chapter gives you an achievement. (So completing the game adds a +1 to your perfect games. Are you listening, achievement hunters? :P )Another good thing is the length of the gameplay (3-4hrs max)If it was any longer, it might've gotten boring. (Unless you're a geek who likes to keep solving puzzles :P )But the length is enough for the art and music to hold you till the end.

Posted: December 14, 2015
												This game works much better as art than it does a game, but it does have some game elements.The main themes the game uses is point-and-click collecting of items on the screen, in addition to the occasional mini-game. It's fairly casual, and might take you a few hours to complete the game. There's no central story that I remember picking up on. Each level follows a different bug that you control, moving around several maps to collect items.Don't expect a whole lot from this game; it's very clear that most of the work went into the graphics, so expect vibrant graphics and basic functionality. I would personally recommend waiting for the game to go under $1 before buying.

Posted: December 15, 2015
												the kind of game that makes you want to make games.put down your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ fps / moba for like 2hrs to play. literally only takes 2hrs unless you are scrub. which you are.hand drawn art is on point as is music. an acid trip you wish you'd have but never will.parrallax, dof and motion are super effective.well paced, occasional puzzles were difficult enough to be engaging and easy enough to not make me hate the game. something very serene about hidden object games when done well.i was disappointed you didn't turn into a butterfly at the end and that hitboxes were off on my 2560x1080 so i had to play at 1920x1080 even tho it looked ♥♥♥♥ing gorgeous in the former.

No tips in this game, no tricks and no tutorials. Have a bug, figure out the rest.Get this if you like pretty things, because as an art book this is great. Fails a bit as a game though, better off as an experience.

												Okay pros unique art style, unique hidden object puzzles.Cons, controls are a bit wonky instead of point and click its point click hold and even then you aren't sure where to go.There is a distinct lack of feedback and lack of explanation as to how to control what is going on.A few  times I had to look up the message board to confirm either my hunch as to what the dev was thinking to solve a puzzle or because I didn't have a clue,If you can get this cheap buy it because it is one of the more unique hidden object games but the dev does need to iron some things out such as the lack of feedback as to what you need to do especially with the seed pods because I stumbled on how to open those by accident.

Posted: May 28, 2016
												Are you an entomologist or botanist who believes in reincarnation and enjoys hallucinogens? Have I got a game for you!Morphopolis is a hidden object type game with some puzzles thrown in intermittently. The puzzles are fairly typical, and not that difficult. I beat the 5 levels in about an hour.While a little psychedelic, the artwork is beautful. The music is also very nice.There are no words in the game, so I'm not exactly clear on the "plot," but it seems to be about a bug that brings larger, dead bugs back to life and inhabits them somehow, which is curious and slightly disturbing, but just try not to focus on that part.All in all, I'd give it a 6 out of 10. Pretty, but otherwise pretty uninteresting. Get it on sale.

Maybe it was the gorgeous visuals, the intresting puzzles or just pure boredom. Whatever it was I am very glad I made the purchase as I enjoyed this game immensely.However it is not without its flaws, firstly the movement of your little aphid is very awkward and slow. It takes some getting used to. Some puzzles are very frustrating not due to difficulty but to poor control. For example one puzzle sees you try to turn piles of seeds into 1 pile using checkers moves. It takes 3 or 4 swipes to make a move and makes what is a fairly simple puzzle a hard slog. Final Rating 8/10

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Morphopolis is a beautiful game with a nice soundtrack. I found it very pleasant to play, though I had a little trouble getting used to the way movement works. (It seems a little wonky when using a mouse.) It's also sometimes a bit obtuse on what you have to do next, but when you're stuck without a goal, just clicking on stuff on the screen will eventually trigger the next one. The puzzles range from easy to difficult. At 3 1/2 hours of gameplay, I think this game is worth it even at full price.

Posted: January 4
												I have mixed feelings about Morphopolis. Review with points would be fairer: 3/5 pts.Well, graphics are cool, with colorful illustrations and good complexity for the environments. The music is relaxing and each scenario makes me curious about some things of bug's universe... And I really enjoyed most puzzles.BUT, the gameplay needs REAL improvements. It's not intuitive, on first level I need to click every thing to understand what does what. I just got the tricks somewhere in levels 3-4. And some other puzzles made me VERY nervous (specially the last one, awekened the worst in me), the ones that need strategic moves to beat.So, if you are impatient, better not get this, for the gameplay and puzzles. But I recommend this game if you really REALLY  R E A L L Y  enjoy puzzles. Then, if you have a bit of patience and want to relax and admire a beautiful art for a couple of hours, that's for you (:

Posted: January 8
												An interesting spin on the old hidden object puzzle game, you control an insect that can follow set paths to get to different screens to find the hidden objects. This was actually really difficult. The art style means that there aren't any 'visual anomalies' to look for that you often find in other traditional hidden object games. Some objects will also be hidden behind another object that you have to solve its puzzle to make it move. On top of that, there's a puzzle to solve in each chapter which proved to be really difficult.It's not perfect. There's little to no explanation on how to do anything in the game. The scenes are very crowded and it can be frustrating to move the insect around or even figure out where to go. I had to use a walkthrough once or twice because game mechanics were not explained and I couldn't progress.Surprisingly enjoyable though.

Posted: January 7
												Morphopolis is an art piece more than a game. The gameplay mechanics are poor at best.Pros: The artwork and soundtrack are beautiful.Cons: The gameplay is abysmal. The "mechanics" might work well on a tablet but I doubt it. Most of this game centers around terrible 80s and 90s video game tropes related to adventure games, those being Find The Hidden Object/Pixels and Solve The Puzzle With No Context.This game seems to be an art student's impression of what would make a great game, sadly, it's nothing more than an abject failure.

Posted: December 14, 2016
Product received for free
Buy it for the aesthetics!The biggest plus point of the game is it's art. And the soothing soundtracks.I loved it and that was the main reason I got myself to playing it.If the aesthetics of the game don't sell it to you, Morphopolis probably isn't for you.There are total 5 chapters in the game and each chapter has 1 hidden object puzzle and 1-2 some other puzzle.Out of those, I had difficulty solving only one or two of them. The rest weren't that difficult.And completing each chapter gives you an achievement. (So completing the game adds a +1 to your perfect games. Are you listening, achievement hunters? :P )Another good thing is the length of the gameplay (3-4hrs max)If it was any longer, it might've gotten boring. (Unless you're a geek who likes to keep solving puzzles :P )But the length is enough for the art and music to hold you till the end.

Posted: February 8
TL;DR: A very simple and very unique point-and-click puzzle game.So, this is a short game about the life of the insects (but not really). It's point&click puzzle game, with very chill vibe to it. The story (if one may call it) is really short and consists of 5 missions, each taking anything from 5 to 20 minutes to complete.Controls are a bit lackluster, but absolutely nothing to worry about in such a short game. Puzzles are pretty simple, except for the very last one (took me around 15 minutes to solve).Visual aesthetics are the main selling point of the game, I think -- hand-drawn insects look pretty unique, I don't think I've seen anything like this game before. It looks an illustration that came alive out of some some old biology book.Overall, this game is a great way to spend an hour, if you don't have anything better to do. I would definitely recommend it to people who enjoy an occasional puzzle or two.Extra points for not having any bugs (except for those that are, you know, actual bugs -- as in, insects)!

Posted: April 19, 2016
												Went in with the same expectations as Tiny Bang Story and Botanicula, but it wasn't quite up there. GameplayYou take control of small insects and you crawl into bigger insects to revive them, which then crawl into bigger insects etc. The game is inspired by games like Machinarium, Botanicula and Tiny Bang Story. It definitely shows! The biggest flaw this game are the controls. They feel stiff and sometimes boring. Your character moves slow and it can be quite frustrating to collect stuff, because you have to wait for the next picture to pan.GraphicsCartoonish art style is the best way to describe this game. It is obvious to see it is drawn by hand with these lucid and fantasy colors. It is a perfect interpretation of what is like being on drugs. It's not my cup of tea, but it definitely has an unique art style.SoundSoundtrack is relaxing, just as it should. You can tell it is here they drew a lot of inspiration from Tiny Bang Story, which is one my favorite soundtracks of all time. Beautiful piano medleys throughout the whole game.VerdictIt is definitely not as good as the more mainstream point-and-click adventure games, but it never claims to be. It is a fun and short game, which all fans of these types of game should experience. The price is definitely worth it too.

content:
Posted: February 22
												It's going to make you want to re-play Botanicula. It's artstyle is definitly it's strongest point, It's got sort of a yellow submarine vibe. Soundtrack fits and that's pretty much it. It's your standard point and click kleptomaniac adventure, you play as an insect who's trying to do an impression of russian nesting dolls by routinely taking over the brains of vegative insects and piloting them into larger insects. There are a couple of clever minigames inbetween the cleptomainiac collecting but there just aren't enough. Sort of my problem with the whole game really, it feels way too short and yet still feels incredibly  padded in every area.Point and click adventure games are one of the oldest forms of game, yet developers still manage to ♥♥♥♥ them up. The walk speed is horrible and the puzzles are never based off logic, although I do like how the game just tells you what objects you need to progress, (rather than doing the normal adventure game rigamarole of throwing every item at a door in the hope it somehow creates progress) it does get pretty boring.It's a shame really, I like the concept, and the art style and music are good and it's got a lot of heart in it; it just stumbles, tripps and♥♥♥♥♥♥s itself in the gameplay and story division.

Posted: June 8, 2016
												Lacks a mid-level save feature, and some levels are very lengthy. Easy to accidentally 'quit' through the use of non-sense arbitrary menu icons instead of text. Does not warn you that you will lose what may amount to 45-60 minutes of gameplay. Controls are god-awful, your insect moves painfully slowly, and will often refuse to follow the commnds of your cursor, deciding to go whichever way it wants. The game has you crawling (craaaawling) around collecting hidden objects, only to find out, after 'beating' the boss, you must go back to collect all these amber blobs around the map. Since it takes forever to navigate through the levels of a screen it's a horrible experience. Walking slowly, trudging up and down the plants. Most of this game feels like filler. One of the puzzles is literally impossible to accomplish without a video (Reconstruct a Plant in Level 4). Some of the puzzles are interesting and well designed, others feel like unguided nonsense. Overall, this is a miss.Great visual design, bad game design.

Posted: April 22
												I enjoyed the art style and the music makes you feel like you're imersed in the natural setting or being a tiny bug. That being said some of the puzzles are annoyingly hard such as the one where you fix the flowers which by the end I had two left and was just clicking around hoping they would stick somewhere(looking nothing like the other pieces) and the Chinese Checkers like one where I swear I clicked and dragged diagonally with nothing happening and then *poof* it worked. Which brings me to the gameplay. Having to click and hold to move is a pain, especially when you're trying to make the character go a certain direction and he just seems to get stuck on nothing, or when trying to click on an object and he moves down or up to the next screen instead; I really feel this would do better with using the arrow keys or atleast WASD. There wasn't really much to the story other than bugs possessing each other which is weird to say the least. So in the end was it frustrating yes, I recommend having a walkthrough on hand, but if you like puzzles I'd say give it a try.
